member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Diagram
member.summary: A Diagram is a Control that includes a that holds some s that display s such as s and s.

remarks.para: Each Diagram has a number of standard objects that it uses to perform its duties. These objects are accessible via the following properties: , , , , , , and various other tool properties.

The is the object that holds and describes all of the data for which s are created and displayed. The purpose of the model is to recognize relationships between the data -- in particular link relationships between nodes and group memberships between nodes. There are different kinds of models, such as , and .
The default model is a . You will typically want to replace it with your own specialized model. The default model does not have an either; you may want to set to true.

The is responsible for creating s corresponding to node data in the model, and for creating s corresponding to link relationships in the model. It notices the insertion or deletion of node data or link data or group-memberships, and updates the diagram appropriately. It maintains collections of the existing and .

You can control the appearance of the nodes and links in the diagram by setting several data template properties: , , . Also, because this is a standard Control, you can set its Control.Template property to a ControlTemplate. If you do not set these properties, its uses default templates to define the appearance of nodes, links, and of the control itself. If the value of a template property changes, the will rebuild the s that are affected.
You can see the definitions of the standard templates in the Generic.XAML file that is in the docs subdirectory of the GoXam installation.

The diagram also maintains the notion of selected parts. The property is an ObservableCollection of the currently selected s. The primary selection is held as the property. You can set to control how many parts may be selected at once. To select a you can set its property.

There are many properties, named "Allow...", that control what operations the user may perform on the parts in the diagram. These correspond to the same named properties on that govern the behavior for those parts in a particular layer. Furthermore for some of these properties there are corresponding properties on , named "...able", that govern the behavior for that individual part. For example, the property corresponds to and to the property . The predicate is false if any of these properties is false.
The implements various standard commands, such as the method and the predicate. These methods are the implementation of the Commands listed as properties of the Commands static class.
The diagram also keeps track of the mouse-down point and last mouse point, in model coordinates: and .

The diagram supports modular behavior for mouse events by implementing "tools". "Mode-less" tools are held in three lists: , , and . The , which defaults to an instance of , searches these lists when a mouse event happens to find the first tool that can run. It then makes that tool the new , where it can continue to process mouse events. When the tool is done, it stops itself, causing the to become the new .

Standard tools include:
for reconnecting an existing
for reshaping the route of a
for resizing a or an element inside a part
for rotating a or an element inside a node
for drawing a new
for moving or (control-)copying selected s
for rubber-band selection of some s within a rectangular area
for panning (scrolling) the diagram
for in-place editing of text
for inserting new s where the user clicks
for selecting s
The diagram also raises various routed events when interesting things happen.
The events include:
The is responsible for positioning all of the s and routing all of the s. The overall positioning of nodes is done by the value of the property. Some s can have their own s.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Diagram.OnApplyTemplate
member.summary: Perform initialization.
member.remarks: This finds the template child that becomes the value of . It calls to create the various standard layers, it raises the event so that you can initialize the 's event handlers or establish data-bindings on its properties, it calls to create s and s from the model's data, and it calls to eventually position the nodes if needed.

member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Diagram.UnloadingClearsPartManager
member.summary: Gets or sets whether when this Diagram is Unloaded, it should clear out all of the 's s and s.
member.value: The initial value is true.

remarks.para: If you expect to temporarily remove this diagram from the visual tree and re-insert it, you will want to set this property to false. The default value of true accommodates the usage pattern where removing the diagram from the visual tree is meant to discard the diagram permanently.
If the diagram is inside a TabControl, this treats the value of UnloadingClearsPartManager as if it were false.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Diagram.Model
member.summary: Gets or sets the that organizes the data to which this diagram is bound.
member.value: The initial value is an instance of . If you want to data-bind this property, set to false.

remarks.para: Replacing this value causes all of the bound s and s to be deleted and re-created from the new model data. The value of (and possibly ) will be updated too.
Models may be shared by multiple Diagrams. One common approach is to have two Diagrams displaying the same Model but using different DataTemplates and sometimes even different Layouts.

member.summary: Gets or sets the point in the panel where the point specified by should be positioned.
member.value: The default value is . If the is not a specific spot, this property and the property are ignored.

remarks.para: This spot specifies the initial point in the at which the of the diagram's should be located. The default values of this property and of cause the top-left corner of the diagram contents to be positioned at the top-left corner of the panel.

This property only has an effect on the initial diagram shown if the property has its default value of and if the property has its default value of a Point whose X or Y values are Double.NaN, and if both spots are specific spots (i.e. are true).

member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Diagram.InitialCenteredNodeData
member.summary: Gets or sets the data object for which the corresponding will be centered in the viewport after an initial layout has completed.
member.value: The default value is null.

remarks.para: One cannot scroll the diagram until the diagram and its have been fully initialized, until the nodes and links have been realized, and until the initial layout has completed, ensuring that all nodes have locations. Rather than calling in an event handler, you can just set this property to refer to some data, and will center the node for you.
Note that if you set both this property and to different data, the latter will take precedence.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.Diagram.CenteredNodeDataProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Diagram.CenteredNodeData
member.summary: Gets or sets the data object for which the corresponding will be centered in the viewport.
member.value: The default value is null.
member.remarks:
You can cause the currently selected node to be automatically centered by binding:
<go:Diagram x:Name="myDiagram" Grid.Row="0" CenteredNodeData="{Binding ElementName=myDiagram, Path=SelectedNode.Data}" />
This calls when the value of this property changes or when a layout completes in .
This property, if non-null, takes precedence over the property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Diagram.CurrentTool
member.summary: Gets or sets the current that handles the diagram's input events.
member.value: Initially this is set to the value of . Setting this to a null value is treated as if it were set to the , because there should always be a currently running tool, except when the diagram is being initialized.

remarks.para: Setting this property to a new tool stops the previous current tool. If the old tool was , this calls its method. Then it calls on it.
This starts the new tool by calling on it.
You can run a modal tool just by setting this property. When that tool is finished it should call or it can set this property to the value of .
Because this property is frequently set, it cannot be used as a data-binding target.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.Diagram.DragSelectingToolProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Diagram.DragSelectingTool
member.summary: Gets or sets the standard mouse-move tool for selecting many objects with a rubber-band rectangle.
member.value: The default value is an instance of .

remarks.para:
For example, you can change the selection policy in XAML by:
<go:Diagram ...> <go:Diagram.DragSelectingTool> <go:DragSelectingTool Include="Intersects" /> </go:Diagram.DragSelectingTool> </go:Diagram>

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.Diagram.PanningToolProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Diagram.PanningTool
member.summary: Gets or sets the standard mouse-move tool for manual panning.
member.value: The default value is an instance of .

remarks.para: Normally the takes precedence, because both tools operate on a left-button-mouse-down in the background followed by a mouse-drag. But precedes this in the list of , so if it is applicable, it is always chosen first.

To enable this mode-less panning tool, you can remove the drag-selecting tool or you can disable that tool by disallowing selection. Remove the tool in WPF XAML by:
<go:Diagram ... DragSelectingTool="{x:Null}" > . . . </go:Diagram>
or remove it in code by:
myDiagram.DragSelectingTool = null;
You can disable user selection by setting the property to false.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.Diagram.DragZoomingToolProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Diagram.DragZoomingTool
member.summary: Gets or sets the non-standard mouse-move tool for manual zooming.
member.value: The default value is null.

remarks.para: Because this property is normally null, there is no standard mode-less drag-zooming tool. You can install this tool by creating an instance of it and setting that diagram property. However, although it can start, the and the are two other background-mouse-drag mode-less tools that are normally present and earlier in the and thus will take precedence over this tool.

To make this mode-less tool effective, you can remove the other two background mouse-dragging tools and install the in XAML:
<go:Diagram ... DragSelectingTool="{x:Null}" PanningTool="{x:Null}" > <go:Diagram.DragZoomingTool> <go:DragZoomingTool /> </go:Diagram.DragZoomingTool> </go:Diagram>
You could also do the same in code:
myDiagram.DragSelectingTool = null; myDiagram.PanningTool = null; myDiagram.DragZoomingTool = new DragZoomingTool();

member.summary: Delete the currently from the .

member.summary: Gets or sets whether deletes only the selected parts or subtrees of selected nodes as well.

remarks.para: When set to , will augment the collection of selected nodes to include their tree children nodes. The resulting collection often will include many s and s that are not .
Links are assumed to go from the parent node to the children nodes, unless is set to "Source".
If you set this property, you might also want to set the property and the property.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.CommandHandler.Group
member.summary: Create a new group node and add the selected parts to that new group.
member.remarks: This creates a new group node by adding a copy of the data to the model, which must support the interface. Each of the selected nodes for which is true is made a member of that new group node. If all of the selected groupable nodes were members of a pre-existing group node, the new group node also becomes a member of that pre-existing group. The new group node becomes the only selected part. This also raises the . All of the changes are performed in an undoable edit.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.CommandHandler.Ungroup
member.summary: For each selected node that is a group, remove the group without removing its members from the diagram.
member.remarks: For each selected node that is a and that is , change all of their member nodes to be members of the group that the selected group node is in. (If the selected group node is a top-level node, i.e. not a member of any group node, its members become top-level nodes too.) All of those selected group nodes are deleted. All of the reparented member nodes are selected. This also raises the . All of the changes are performed in an undoable edit.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.BooleanBrushConverter
member.summary: Convert a boolean to one of two Brushes.

remarks.para: You can specify a brush for when the boolean is True and another one for when the boolean is False, either by setting the or properties, or by setting the or properties which will also set the corresponding brush property to a SolidColorBrush of that color.

Typically you will create an instance (or two) of this converter class as resources. For example:
<go:BooleanBrushConverter x:Key="theBooleanBrushConverter" TrueColor="DodgerBlue"> <go:BooleanBrushConverter.FalseBrush> <LinearGradientBrush . . .> . . . </LinearGradientBrush> </go:BooleanBrushConverter.FalseBrush> </go:BooleanBrushConverter>

One possible use for this converter is to indicate selection:
<DataTemplate x:Key="NodeTemplate2"> <Border BorderBrush="Gray" BorderThickness="1" Background="{Binding Path=Part.IsSelected, Converter={StaticResource theBooleanBrushConverter}}" go:Node.Location="{Binding Path=Data.Location, Mode=TwoWay}"> <StackPanel Orientation="Vertical"> <Ellipse Fill="Blue" Width="20" Height="20" HorizontalAlignment="Center" go:Node.LinkableFrom="True" go:Node.LinkableTo="True" Cursor="Arrow" go:Node.FromSpot="AllSides" go:Node.ToSpot="AllSides"/> <TextBlock x:Name="Text" Text="{Binding Path=Data.Key}" HorizontalAlignment="Center" /> </StackPanel> </Border> </DataTemplate>
When the node is not selected, the background is a linear gradient brush. When the node is selected, the background is a solid DodgerBlue.
By default true converts to the system highlight color/brush (typically bluish) and false converts to the system highlight text color/brush (typically white).

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.BooleanStringConverter
member.summary: Convert a boolean to one of two strings.

remarks.para:
Typically you will create an instance of this as a resource. For example, one possible use of this converter:
<go:BooleanStringConverter x:Key="theBooleanLayerConverter" TrueString="Foreground" FalseString="" />
<DataTemplate> <Border . . . go:Part.LayerName="{Binding Path=Part.IsSelected, Converter={StaticResource theBooleanLayerConverter}}"> . . . </Border> </DataTemplate>
When the node is selected, the node is moved to the named "Foreground". When the node is no longer selected, the node is moved to the default layer, named with the empty string.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.GridPattern
member.summary: This panel is used to draw regular grid patterns.

remarks.para: The typical will have pairs of Paths as child elements. Each Path will have the attached property set to indicate whether the path should be a line or a bar, and whether the path has repeated horizontal or vertical segments.
The property controls the size of each cell.

A simple grid is defined by:
<go:GridPattern CellSize="10 10" Width="200" Height="200"> <Path Stroke="LightGray" StrokeThickness="1" go:GridPattern.Figure="HorizontalLine" /> <Path Stroke="LightGray" StrokeThickness="1" go:GridPattern.Figure="VerticalLine" /> </go:GridPattern>

You can also have repeating variations of the lines by having multiple Paths, where those after the first one in each direction have the attached property to set integer values larger than one. The interval describes how often that path should be drawn. Note that the interval is an integer not a double because it is a multiple. So in the follow example, once every five lines there is a Gray line instead of a LightGray line -- in other words every 10 model units the line is LightGray, except that every 50 model units the line is Gray.
<go:GridPattern CellSize="10 10" Width="200" Height="200"> <Path Stroke="LightGray" StrokeThickness="1" go:GridPattern.Figure="HorizontalLine" /> <Path Stroke="LightGray" StrokeThickness="1" go:GridPattern.Figure="VerticalLine" /> <Path Stroke="Gray" StrokeThickness="1" go:GridPattern.Figure="HorizontalLine" go:GridPattern.Interval="5" /> <Path Stroke="Gray" StrokeThickness="1" go:GridPattern.Figure="VerticalLine" go:GridPattern.Interval="5" /> </go:GridPattern>

You can have alternating green bars by:
<go:GridPattern CellSize="50 50" Width="200" Height="200"> <Path Fill="LightGreen" go:GridPattern.Figure="HorizontalBar" go:GridPattern.Interval="2" /> </go:GridPattern>

A GridPattern may be the value of a diagram's property. You will need to set to true. Such a GridPattern is automatically arranged to occupy the whole 's viewport; so you should not set its Width or Height. The GridPattern may be supplied as a property element value in XAML or as a DataTemplate specified as the diagram's . If no property and no are supplied, it will use a default template.
You should not apply any transformations to the Paths; that is reserved for GoXam's use. If the GridPattern is the whole diagram's , you should not apply any transformations to it at all.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.GridFigure
member.summary: This enumeration describes how Path elements that are children of a may be used to draw a regular grid.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.GridFigure.None
member.summary: The default value -- not used by as a regular grid line or bar.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.GridFigure.HorizontalLine
member.summary: Draw regular horizontal lines; supply "Stroke..." properties to the Path.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.GridFigure.VerticalLine
member.summary: Draw regular vertical lines; supply "Stroke..." properties to the Path.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.GridFigure.HorizontalBar
member.summary: Draw regular horizontal bars; supply the "Fill" property to the Path. The brush fill applies to the whole , not to each bar. Control the breadth of each bar in units of the cell size by setting the attached .

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.GridFigure.VerticalBar
member.summary: Draw regular vertical bars; supply the "Fill" property to the Path. The brush fill applies to the whole , not to each bar. Control the breadth of each bar in units of the cell size by setting the attached .

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.GridFigure.HorizontalDot
member.summary: Draw regular dots along horizontal lines at the grid points. You need to supply the Stroke brush property to give each dot a color. The StrokeThickness specifies the size of each dot. If you do not specify a non-zero StrokeThickness, it will be set to 1. will automatically set the other "Stroke..." properties.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.GridFigure.VerticalDot
member.summary: Draw regular dots along vertical lines at the grid points. You need to supply the Stroke brush property to give each dot a color. The StrokeThickness specifies the size of each dot. If you do not specify a non-zero StrokeThickness, it will be set to 1. will automatically set the other "Stroke..." properties.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.GridFigure.HorizontalCross
member.summary: Draw horizontal lines for crosses at the grid points. You need to supply the Stroke brush property to give each line a color. If you do not specify a non-zero StrokeThickness, it will be set to 1. will automatically set the other "Stroke..." properties. Control the length of each dash by setting the .

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.GridFigure.VerticalCross
member.summary: Draw vertical lines for crosses at the grid points. You need to supply the Stroke brush property to give each line a color. If you do not specify a non-zero StrokeThickness, it will be set to 1. will automatically set the other "Stroke..." properties. Control the length of each dash by setting the .

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.XHelper
member.summary: This static class holds various methods that are useful in saving and loading model data to and from Linq for XML XElements.

remarks.para: There are three kinds of methods defined in this class. There are basic data conversion methods, converting data types to and from Strings. There are methods that produce XAttributes and XElements containing given some data. There are methods that get data from XAttributes and XElements.

The conversion method names are all prefixed with "To". They use the XmlConvert methods for achieving their results. For the basic data types (String, bool, int, Guid, and double), the conversion methods are the same as the equivalent XmlConvert methods. For the additional data types (Point, Size, Rect, Thickness) the conversion methods assume the numbers are separated by spaces.

When generating XML using Linq for XML you will often want to avoid generating attributes or elements when the values are the same as the property defaults. To help with that situation the methods named "Attribute" take the attribute name, a property value, and the property's default value. If the value is null or if the value is equal to the default value, the method returns null; otherwise it returns a new XAttribute. This is convenient when building an XElement.

When consuming XML using Linq for XML you need to deal with situations where the expected attribute or child element is not present or where the value is in the wrong format or for some other reason cannot be converted to the expected data type. To help with these cases the methods named "Read" take the attribute name, the XElement on which the attribute may exist, and the default value for that property. If the XElement is null, or if it has no XAttribute with the given name, or if there is an exception converting the string value to the expected data type, it will return the default value.

There are also generic methods for handling enumerations and for sequences of data. For data sequences, of type IEnumerable, the methods will generate and expect to consume child elements, one for each item. You will need to specify the name of those child elements, and the conversion function for the item data type.
For examples of how to use these methods, look at the descriptions of the predefined data methods for making elements and loading data from them: , , , , , , ,

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.DiagramModel
member.summary: The common base class for all predefined model classes.

remarks.para: This class is not a generic class, unlike the predefined model classes (, , ).

This class defines several kinds of members:
a few properties: , ,
the event and some methods for raising that event
the property and some methods for executing state changes due to an undo or redo
some methods for starting and finishing edits (i.e. groups of state changes)
the property

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.DiagramModel.#ctor
member.summary: The constructor is protected because this class is abstract.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.DiagramModel.Initializing
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the model is being constructed or re-constructed.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.DiagramModel.Reinitialize
member.summary: Reset the fields that should not be shared from a copy created by .
member.remarks: If you override this method because you have added some fields, be sure to call the base method too.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.DiagramModel.Name
member.summary: A name for this model.
member.value: By default this is an empty string. The value must not be null.
member.remarks: This is mostly used to help distinguish between different models of the same type.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.DiagramModel.DataFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the format of this model's data.
member.value: By default this is the fully qualified name of this model type. This property cannot be set to null.
member.remarks: This string is used by clipboard and drag-and-drop operations to distinguish between different and presumably incompatible data sources. You may wish to provide different values in order to prevent data from being transferred to other applications that are using the same model class.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.DiagramModel.Modifiable
member.summary: Gets or sets whether various model-changing methods are enabled.
member.value: By default this value is false.

remarks.para: When false, this property disables methods named "Add...", "Modify...", or "Remove...".
But note that this property does not and cannot affect the "modifiability" or "read-only"-ness of model data, since the data classes may have no knowledge about this model class and this property.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether this model is considered changed from an earlier state.
member.value: true if this model has been marked as having been modified, if the has recorded any changes, or if an undo has been performed without a corresponding redo.

remarks.para: This property is set to true in . Setting this property does not raise a event.

Although you can set this property at any time, the value of will continue to be true as long as there have been changes made to the model and you are using an . Any modifications to a model or one of its parts will result in setting to true and in adding fromport to the list, which holds all of the changes for undo/redo.

When using an UndoManager, you should be making all changes within a transaction. After finishing or rolling back a transaction, you can set to false, and then it will remain false until another change is made to the model.
When there is no , this property is implemented as only a simple boolean state variable.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.ValidCycle.NotDirectedFast

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.ValidCycle.DestinationTree
member.summary: Any number of destination links may go out of a port, but at most one source link may come into a port, and there are no directed cycles.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.ValidCycle.SourceTree
member.summary: Any number of source links may come into a port, but at most one destination link may go out of a port, and there are no directed cycles.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.TreeModelNodeData`1
member.summary: A simple representation of node data for that supports property change notification, copying, and undo via the INotifyPropertyChanged, ICloneable, and interfaces.
member.typeparam: the Type of a value uniquely identifying a node data in the model

remarks.para:
This provides a standard implementation of
data that represents nodes and includes a property for referring to the "parent" node, and a property for holding a list of "children" nodes. You can use this class if you do not already have your own application class holding information about nodes and if you want to inherit from an existing class so that you can just add your own properties. Here's a simple example:

Note that property setters need to raise the model's Changed event, so that the model knows about changes in the data and can then update the diagram. You should call only when the value has actually changed, and you should pass both the previous and the new values, in order to support undo/redo.

You should override the method if the fields contain data that should not be shared between copies. The properties that you define should also be serializable, in order for the data to be copiable, especially to and from the clipboard.
If you add properties to this node data class, and if you are using the and methods, you should override the and methods to add new attributes and/or elements as needed,

Normally, each should have a unique value within the model. You can maintain that yourself, by setting the to unique values before adding the node data to the model's collection of nodes. Or you can ensure this by overriding the
method. The override (or the setting of the same-named delegate in ) is required if nodes might be copied within the model.

If you want each node to keep a reference to its "parent" node, you can use the property. If you want each node to keep a list of reference to its "children" nodes, you can use the property, which is a list of node keys. You can use both and at the same time.

member.summary: The default constructor produces an empty object.
member.remarks: If the NodeKey is Guid, this automatically assigns the to be a new Guid.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.TreeModelNodeData`1.#ctor(`0)
member.summary: This constructor also initializes the property.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.TreeModelNodeData`1.Clone
member.summary: Create a copy of this data; this implements the ICloneable interface.

remarks.para: When you add your own state in a subclass, and when you expect to be able to copy the data, you should override this method in your derived class when it has some fields that are object references. Your override method should first call base.Clone() to get the newly copied object. The result should be the object you return, after performing any other deeper copying of referenced objects that you deem necessary, and after removing references that should not be shared (such as to cached data structures).

The standard implementation of this method is to do a shallow copy, by Object.MemberwiseClone(), and reinitialize the and properties. You do not need to override this method if you have only added some fields/properties that are values or are references to intentionally shared objects.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphModelNodeData`1
member.summary: A simple representation of node data for that supports property change notification, copying, and undo via the INotifyPropertyChanged, ICloneable, and interfaces.
member.typeparam: the Type of a value uniquely identifying a node data in the model

remarks.para:
This provides a standard implementation of
data that represents nodes and includes properties for collections of adjacent node keys, in either direction, and includes properties for specifying the containing subgraph node key and/or the collection of member node keys. You can use this class if you do not already have your own application class holding information about nodes and if you want to inherit from an existing class so that you can just add your own properties. Here's a simple example:

Note that property setters need to raise the model's Changed event, so that the model knows about changes in the data and can then update the diagram. You should call only when the value has actually changed, and you should pass both the previous and the new values, in order to support undo/redo.

You should override the method if the fields contain data that should not be shared between copies. The properties that you define should also be serializable, in order for the data to be copiable, especially to and from the clipboard.
If you add properties to this node data class, and if you are using the and methods, you should override the and methods to add new attributes and/or elements as needed,

Normally, each should have a unique value within the model. You can maintain that yourself, by setting the to unique values before adding the node data to the model's collection of nodes. Or you can ensure this by overriding the
method. The override (or the setting of the same-named delegate in ) is required if nodes might be copied within the model.

If you want each node to keep a list of nodes for which there are links to those nodes coming out of this node data, you can use the property, which is a list of node keys. If you want each node to keep a list of nodes from which there are links coming into this node data, you can use the property, which is a list of node keys. You can use both lists at the same time.

If you want each node to keep a "reference" to the containing ("parent") group, you can use the property. If you want subgraph data to keep a list of "references" to the contained ("children") nodes, you can use the property. You can use both properties at the same time.

data that represents nodes with support for subgraphs, including properties for specifying the containing subgraph node key and/or the collection of member node keys. You can use this class if you do not already have your own application class holding information about nodes and if you want to inherit from an existing class so that you can just add your own properties. Note that property setters need to raise the model's Changed event, so that the model knows about changes in the data and can then update the diagram. You should call only when the value has actually changed, and you should pass both the previous and the new values, in order to support undo/redo.

You should override the method if the fields contain data that should not be shared between copies. The properties that you define should also be serializable, in order for the data to be copiable, especially to and from the clipboard.
If you add properties to this node data class, and if you are using the and methods, you should override the and methods to add new attributes and/or elements as needed,

Normally, each should have a unique value within the model. You can maintain that yourself, by setting the to unique values before adding the node data to the model's collection of nodes. Or you can ensure this by overriding the
method. The override (or the setting of the same-named delegate in ) is required if nodes might be copied within the model.

If you want each node to keep a "reference" to the containing ("parent") group, you can use the property. If you want subgraph data to keep a list of "references" to the contained ("children") nodes, you can use the property. You can use both properties at the same time.
This class is not useful with or .

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphLinksModelNodeData`1.Clone
member.summary: Create a copy of this data; this implements the ICloneable interface.

remarks.para: When you add your own state in a subclass, and when you expect to be able to copy the data, you should override this method in your derived class when it has some fields that are object references. Your override method should first call base.Clone() to get the newly copied object. The result should be the object you return, after performing any other deeper copying of referenced objects that you deem necessary, and after removing references that should not be shared (such as to cached data structures).

The standard implementation of this method is to do a shallow copy, by Object.MemberwiseClone(), and reinitialize the and properties. You do not need to override this method if you have only added some fields/properties that are values or are references to intentionally shared objects.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphLinksModelLinkData`2
member.summary: A simple representation of link data that supports property change notification, copying, and undo via the INotifyPropertyChanged, ICloneable, and interfaces.
member.typeparam: the Type of a value uniquely identifying a node data in the model
the Type of an optional value that helps distinguish different "ports" on a node

remarks.para:
This provides a standard implementation of
data that represents links, including properties that are "references" to the two nodes at each end of the link and optional "port" parameter information at both ends. You can use this class if you do not already have your own application class holding information about links and if you want to inherit from an existing class so that you can just add your own properties. Here's a simple example:

Note that property setters need to raise the model's Changed event, so that the model knows about changes in the data and can then update the diagram. You should call only when the value has actually changed, and you should pass both the previous and the new values, in order to support undo/redo.
The properties that you define should also be serializable, in order for the data to be copiable, especially to and from the clipboard. You should override the method.

In the sample above, the is declared to be a string, which is used as the way to uniquely refer to node data. The is declared to be a string, which is useful if you want to distinguish between multiple "ports" on a single node. However, if your nodes only have a single port, you can ignore the port parameter information, and the type does not really matter, although string is recommended for compatibility with the implementation of methods that deal with ports.
This class is not useful with or .

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.UniversalLinkData
member.summary: This simple class is handy with many s or with , so that for many cases you do not need to define your own link data class inheriting from .

remarks.para: The node data type can be any Object; the (optional) port parameter information is assumed to be of type String. There are constructors for most of the common uses.
For reasons of both compile-time type checking and run-time efficiency, we recommend defining your own data class derived from . Doing so also permits the addition of application-specific properties.
This class is not useful with or .

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.IDiagramModel
member.summary: All diagram models implement this interface or an interface that inherits from this interface.

remarks.para: This is reponsible for defining relationships between nodes, involving links and grouping. It does not know about any FrameworkElements (including or or ). It just knows about .NET CLR objects as data of type or about more specific types when instantiating one of the generic classes. It is vaguely analogous to a CollectionView, providing additional organization of the source data. It defines a graph from the data instead of imposing a total ordering on it and filtering/sorting/grouping it. It also supports two-pass copying of existing data and undo/redo support via an .

There are four categories of members in this interface: updating, navigation, modification, and miscellaneous. The updating methods need to be called when there has been a change to the data, so that the model can be kept up-to-date with the data. The navigation methods support examining the diagram and traversing the graph defined by the nodes and links in the diagram. The modification methods are used to alter the diagram. The miscellaneous methods and properties include support for model change notification, for undo/redo, for edits, and for data transfer. Additional categories of members exist in each of the model classes.

The most important member of this interface is the property, the collection of node data defining the graph. You will need to set it before anything can be seen in your . The model will look at each node data in that collection to discover the relationships that will form the graph. The methods and properties for discovering a graph from the data depend on the kind of model, so they are not part of this interface.

As data is added or removed from the model, or as data is modified, the graph implied by the data changes. Whenever the data is modified, the model must be notified. The model interfaces (both this interface and more specific interfaces inheriting from this interface) have a category of methods for being notified of data changes. This basic interface includes methods such as , , and . More specific kinds of models have additional methods, such as: , , , , and . Updating methods have names that start with "Do".

Of course if your data is unchanging, neither by application code nor by the user, you will not need to be concerned about keeping the model up-to-date. But if your data might change, .NET provides some standard interfaces for change notification that you should use if you want successful data binding.

The INotifyPropertyChanged interface (in the System.ComponentModel namespace) is commonly used for notification of property changes. The diagram model classes automatically register themselves as INotifyPropertyChanged.PropertyChanged event listeners for each of the data objects that are in the collection so that they can be updated if a model-relevant property changes in a data object. We suggest that you have your node data class implement this interface, but that you use the class for event arguments instead of PropertyChangedEventArgs.

In addition, Microsoft recommends implementing the INotifyCollectionChanged interface (in the System.Collections.Specialized namespace) for providing change notification of collection objects. .NET offers the ObservableCollection<T> class as a standard collection that implements INotifyCollectionChanged. So if the collection you supply as the value of implements this interface, the model will automatically call the and methods for you. Similarly, for the data properties that are expected to be collections, (such as the collection of tree children nodes for a data node in the tree model), we suggest you use ObservableCollection<T>. Note that the optional data classes that we provide for your use, if you do not already have your own data classes, implement INotifyPropertyChanged and make use of ObservableCollection<T>. An example is .

The generic model classes have a parameterized type, NodeType, that denotes the type of the node data that it contains. That of course is the required type of each item in the collection. Furthermore, all of the methods that operate on node data take and/or return that type. This design provides for better type checking at compile time and potentially better performance at run time.

But and its subinterfaces are not generic. Their methods all take and/or return data of type Object instead of a parameterized type. This "universality" is necessary because the diagram control is not a generic class.

Unlike most controls that bind to a list of items, diagrams involve relationships between the items that are much more general than just the order in the list. This is achieved by interpreting some property values as "references" to other data. Such references might be implemented as .NET CLR references (i.e. pointers). However, it is also common to use other values, such as strings or numbers, as the references. Such a scheme requires being able to identify each data object with a unique value.

The generic model class have another parameterized type, NodeKey, that denotes the type of the values that refer to node data. When the abstract references are actually .NET CLR references, the NodeKey type will be the same as the NodeType type. But more often the NodeKey will be something like String or int.

Normally the expectation is that the key value for each node data does not change. However, the models do support such a circumstance -- make sure the method is called right after changing a node's key.
The method is useful for finding a node data given its key. To find out if a node data is in the collection, call the predicate.

The models have a number of methods that are useful for examining or navigating. These method names tend to start with "Get" or "Is". For "link" relationships, the following methods apply to all models: , , , . Particular kinds of models have additional methods for traversing graphs, such as: , , , , , and . Note that the models will have similar protected (not public) methods that actually implement the corresponding behavior on the data. There will be virtual so that your model implementation can customize or optimize how the method performs the operation.

The models also have methods for modifying. These method names start with "Modify", "Add", or "Remove". For nodes, there are and . For links, there are and . Furthermore, particular kinds of models have additional methods for changing relationships, such as: , , , , and . Note that the models will have similar protected (not public) methods that actually implement the corresponding behavior on the data. There will be virtual so that your model implementation can customize or optimize how the method performs the modification.
Finally, there is the property, that should disable user actions that would modify the model, and that causes errors when you call a model-modifying method anyway.

Models support a two-pass copying process. A single pass copy is insufficient because some "references" cannot be made before all objects have been copied -- those references need to be fixed-up afterwards, in a second pass. Let's say that we have two objects to be copied, A and B, and that A has a string property that refers to B by its name, "B". After making the two copied objects, A2 and B2, A2's reference will typically still be "B". The second copy pass will operate on A2 and give it a chance to look for the original "B" data, to find the copied B2 data, and to change A2's reference to be "B2".

The principal copying method is . This first makes copies of all the data to be copied, and then iterates over them again, fixing up the references. You may need to override protected virtual methods whose names start with "Copy" in order to correctly construct copies of your data in the first pass, and in order to correctly fix references to other data in the second pass.
Even after the two-pass copying process has finished, there may still be unresolved references.
For convenience in making a copy of a node and adding it to the model, there is also the method.

Depending on the application, not all relationships should be possible. Models provide support for link relationships with the method. There are more specific model predicates for IsRelinkValid: , , and . offers similar support for the group-member relationship in . The diagram control uses these methods for deciding which user actions are permissible. The model classes add support for customizing these methods.

Each model is not only a consumer of events on its data but is also a generator events, to allow model consumers such as the diagram control to keep themselves up-to-date with the model. is an enumeration that lists all of the kinds of changes that can happen to the predefined model classes. Whenever there is a change to a model, the code calls or a similar method to notify model consumers. The property is automatically set to true as events are raised.

Each model also supports undo and redo, using an that records events. Because also implements , it is very easy for the undo manager to remember the changes in a manner that makes them easy to undo or redo. But note that the property is initially null; you will need to set this property before any actions can be recorded and then undone. When you want to make transient changes that you do not want to be recorded by the undo manager, you can temporarily set to true.

As you add state to your data or to your model, you may need to add code that implements state changing as needed for undo and redo. This can be done either by overriding a model method or a data method if the data implements .

A single user gesture or command may result in many model/data changes. These all want to be treated as a single undo-able action. You can group such changes together by calling and . If after a you don't want to commit the changes, you can call , which not only ends the transaction but also automatically "undoes" all of the changes since the call to .

remarks.para: This is used for model update, when the model data has changed and the model itself needs to be updated to reflect those changes. Note that this method is universal, because it can only assume the node data is of type . The corresponding methods in the generic model classes operate on a specific node data type.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.ITreeModel
member.summary: This kind of diagram model only supports tree-structured relationships.

remarks.para: Each node data may have a reference to a "parent" node. Each node data may have a collection of references to "children" nodes. All references are by key values.
This kind of model assumes the links are implicit from the references in the lists. If you want to use separate data structures to explicitly represent link information, use the .

This model does not support links that would form a cycle, including reflexive links. Nor does it support more than one link between any pair of nodes. If you need to model multiple links between nodes, use the .
There are three categories of methods: updating, navigation, and modification.

The updating methods need to be called when there has been a change to the data, so that the model can be kept up-to-date. These methods include changes to the "parent" node key: . These methods also include changes to the collection of "children" node keys: , , .
The navigation methods support examining and traversing the graph. Some of these methods are actually defined in the base interface, . , , , and . But this interface adds a few more methods: and .

The modification methods are used to alter the graph. A number of these methods are defined in , such as , , , , and . But this interface adds several methods. For the "parent" node keys: . For the collection of "children" node keys: , , .
Note that this interface is universal, because it can only assume the node data is of type . The corresponding methods in the generic model classes operate on and return a specific node data type.

Note that this method is universal, because it can only assume the node data is of type . The corresponding methods in the generic model classes operate on and return a specific node data type.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.IConnectedModel
member.summary: A model that supports directed link relationships between nodes, with the relationship information stored on each node as collections of connected nodes.

remarks.para: Each node data has two collections of references to other nodes: one that lists the nodes from which there are links connecting to this node, and one that lists the nodes to which there are links connecting from this node. All node references are by node data key value.
This kind of model assumes the links are implicit from the references in the lists. If you want to use separate data structures to explicitly represent link information, use the .

Although this model supports links between any pair of nodes in either or both directions, and supports reflexive links from a node to itself, it does not support more than one link between any pair of nodes in the same direction. If you need to model multiple links between nodes, use the .
There are three categories of methods: updating, navigation, and modification.

The updating methods need to be called when there has been a change to the data, so that the model can be kept up-to-date. These methods include changes to the collection of "from" node keys: , , . These methods also include changes to the collection of "to" node keys: , , .
The navigation methods support examining and traversing the graph. These methods are actually defined in the base interface, . , , , , , and .

The modification methods are used to alter the graph. A number of these methods are defined in , such as , , , , and . But this interface adds several methods. For the collection of "from" node keys: , , . For the collection of "to" node keys: , , .
Note that this interface is universal, because it can only assume the node data is of type . The corresponding methods in the generic model classes operate on and return a specific node data type.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.ILinksModel
member.summary: A model that supports directed link relationships between nodes, with the relationship information stored in separate link data structures.

remarks.para: Link relationship information is found in link data held in the collection property. If you want a simpler model where the link relationship information is stored in a list on each node data, use the .

This model can support any number of links between any pair of nodes. Furthermore, this model supports additional information at each end of the link, to distinguish between different "ports" on each node.

Links are nominally directional, each "coming from a node" and "going to a node". However, if you want to model undirected relationships, you can use the methods that ignore the direction of the links.
There are three categories of methods: updating, navigation, and modification.

The updating methods need to be called when there has been a change to the data, so that the model can be kept up-to-date. These methods include changes to the collection of link data: and . They also include methods involving changes to the state of the link data: and .

The navigation methods support examining and traversing the graph. Some methods working on node data are actually defined in the base interface, . , , , , , and . But this interface adds a number of methods that also work on node data: , , , , , . And there are methods that work on link data: , , , . And there are methods that involve a link data that has a node data as a "label": , , , and .

The modification methods are used to alter the graph. A number of these methods working on node data are defined in , such as , , , , and . But this interface adds several methods working on link data: , , , , , and .
Note that this interface is universal, because it can only assume the node data is of type . The corresponding methods in the generic model classes operate on and return a specific node data type.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.IGroupsModel
member.summary: A model that supports a grouping relationship between nodes, with the relationship information stored on each node as collections of related nodes.

remarks.para: Each node data can be a group (i.e. a node "container") or not (i.e. an "atomic" node). It is assumed that a node data cannot dynamically switch between being a group or not. Each node data can have a list of references to "member" nodes. All node references are by node data key value.

This kind of model assumes the grouping is implicit from these references. At this time we do not support a model where the grouping information is explicitly provided by data structures different from the node data.
There are three categories of methods: updating, navigation, and modification.
The updating methods need to be called when there has been a change to the data, so that the model can be kept up-to-date. These methods include changes to the collection of "member" node keys: , , .
The navigation methods support examining and traversing the graph. One such method is actually defined in the base interface, . This interface adds the following methods: , , , and .
The modification methods are used to alter the graph. A number of these methods are defined in , such as and . But this interface adds several methods: , , .
Note that this interface is universal, because it can only assume the node data is of type . The corresponding methods in the generic model classes operate on and return a specific node data type.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.ISubGraphModel
member.summary: The subgraph model is a kind of grouping model that limits each node (including subgraphs) to be a member of at most one group.

remarks.para: The restriction that each node can have at most one container node means that there is basically a property for each node data that is a reference to its container node, if any.
When that property is changed, must be called. You can get the container group by calling . You can set the container group by calling .
Note that this interface is universal, because it can only assume the node data is of type . The corresponding methods in the generic model classes operate on and return a specific node data type.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.ISubGraphLinksModel
member.summary: This is a that also supports link data ().

remarks.para: This model is basically a that automatically assigns links to belong to groups. There are two methods, one to get the containing group for a link (if any), , and one to get all of the link data that are members of a group, .
Because membership of links in groups is automatically computed, there are no modification or updating methods in this interface.
Note that this interface is universal, because it can only assume the node data is of type . The corresponding methods in the generic model classes operate on and return a specific node data type.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphLinksModel`4.NodeKeyIsNodeData
member.summary: Gets or sets whether all node data are also their own keys.
member.value: The default value is false. For this to be set to true, the type and the types must be the same.

remarks.para: This is used for model discovery. It is an optimization that avoids the use of an additional hash table mapping values to their data, and permits other optimizations as well. This can often be set to true when "references" to nodes are actually using .NET CLR references (i.e. "pointers") instead of values such as integer, strings, GUIDs et al.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphLinksModel`4.NodeKeyReferenceAutoInserts
member.summary: Gets or sets whether a reference, when is true, automatically inserts the node into .
member.value: The default value is false.
member.remarks: This property only has an effect when is true. calls if the referred-to node is not already known to be in the collection.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphLinksModel`4.MakeNodeKeyUnique(`0)
member.summary: This method is called when a duplicate key has been found.
member.returns: true to accept the data as a node after having made the key unique in the model; false to ignore this data.

remarks.para: This is used for model discovery. When a node data is added to the collection, checks for a duplicate key value. If it is a duplicate key, this method is called to either modify the node data to have a unique key, or to return false to avoid adding the data to this model. (However, the duplicate key node data will still be in the collection.)
This method is frequently overridden to implement the desired policy for your particular application model.
When the user copies selected nodes into a diagram, it is likely that this method will be called.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphLinksModel`4.ClearUnresolvedReferences
member.summary: Forget all unresolved delayed or forward references.

remarks.para: The model may learn about node data in any order, so references to nodes may be unresolvable until later, perhaps never. Call this method to clear the internal table that keeps track of s that are not yet defined.
This is called when setting a number of property path properties, because a model property path change can completely alter the references each node data might be making.

member.summary: This is called repeatedly by , once for each known delayed or forward node reference.
member.remarks: Depending on the situation, you may want to create and in order to resolve a reference. Or you may want to ignore it, and later call to make sure no future node data addition might resolve the reference.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphLinksModel`4.CopyNode1(`0,Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphLinksModel{`0,`1,`2,`3}.CopyDictionary)
member.summary: This is the first pass of copying node data, responsible for constructing a copy and copying most of its properties.
member.param: the dictionary mapping original objects to copied objects
member.returns: the copied node data

remarks.para: By default this handles ICloneable or serializable objects. But you may want to override this method to customize which properties get copied or how they are copied or to provide a faster implementation.

This does NOT ensure that the copied node data has a unique key. You must do that before adding it to the collection, either by overriding the data's Clone method, by declaring the data Serializable (WPF), or by overriding this method. Or you can override the method that is called when data is added to the collection of the model.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphLinksModel`4.CopyNode2(`0,Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphLinksModel{`0,`1,`2,`3}.CopyDictionary,`0,`0,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0})
member.summary: This is the second pass of copying node data, responsible for fixing up references to other objects.
member.param: the original node data
the dictionary mapping original objects to copied objects
the copied node data
for convenience, the copied "parent" node data
for convenience, a list of newly copied member nodes

remarks.para: You will want to override this method if the node data should have any references to copied data. Otherwise the copied node will appear to have links to the original nodes, not to the copied nodes.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphLinksModel`4.CopyLink1(`3,Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphLinksModel{`0,`1,`2,`3}.CopyDictionary)
member.summary: This is the first pass of copying link data, responsible for constructing a copy and copying most of its properties.
member.param: the dictionary mapping original objects to copied objects
member.returns: the copied link data

remarks.para: By default this handles ICloneable or serializable (WPF) objects. But you may want to override this method to customize which properties get copied or how they are copied or to provide a faster implementation.
The resulting new link data may (temporarily) continue to refer to the same nodes/ports as the original did. The second pass, , should fix up those references.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphLinksModel`4.CopyLink2(`3,Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphLinksModel{`0,`1,`2,`3}.CopyDictionary,`3,`0,`0,`0)

member.param: the original link data
the dictionary mapping original objects to copied objects
the copied link data
for convenience, the copied "from" node
for convenience, the copied "to" node
for convenience, the copied "label" node

remarks.para: You will want to override this method if the link data should have any references to copied data. Otherwise the copied link will appear to connect the original nodes, not the copied nodes.
When is (the default value), if either or is null, this will remove the copied link from the model, to avoid having disconnected links.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphLinksModel`4.DataCollection
member.summary: This nested class is a serializable collection of node data and link data.

remarks.para: This is used in various circumstances where there is a collection of node data and link data, particularly for copying. If the node data and link data are serializable, this collection can be serialized, which is useful when copying to the clipboard or pasting from it.

Although this nested type is not a generic class, it is parameterized by the NodeType, NodeKey, PortKey, and LinkType type parameters of the containing generic model class. You should call to allocate an instance.

member.summary: This nested class is used during copying to hold a mapping of original nodes to newly copied nodes and original links to newly copied links.

remarks.para: This is used during the two-pass copying process to keep track of which newly copied node data correspond to which original node data and which newly copied link data correspond to which original link data.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphLinksModel`4.AddCollectionCopy(Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphLinksModel{`0,`1,`2,`3}.DataCollection,Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphLinksModel{`0,`1,`2,`3}.CopyDictionary)
member.summary: Copy existing node and link data and add to this model.
member.param: the collection of data to be copied
the used to keep track of copied objects; if null, the method will call , use it, and return it
member.returns: the updated copy dictionary, mapping original data to copied data

remarks.para: The primary purpose of this method is to perform a two-pass copy of a part of a diagram, and add the resulting data to this model.
Of course you can add data without copying them by calling and or by just adding them directly to the and .
This calls on the source model to allow it to extend the collection to include parts that it thinks should be in the collection.
Then it calls on this, the destination model, to allow it to prepopulate the if it wants to guide the copying process to control the sharing of references in the copied parts.

The first pass copies all of the nodes that are not already in the copy dictionary, by calling . If the call returns a node data, it is added to this model by calling and remembered in the copy dictionary, mapped to the original node data.

The first pass also copies all of the links that are not already in the copy dictionary, by calling . If the call returns a link data, it is added to this model by calling and remembered in the copy dictionary, mapped to the original link data.

The second pass fixes up references in all of the copied nodes by calling . It passes as arguments both the original node data and the copied node data, as well as the newly copied group node, if any, and a list of any member nodes.

The second pass also fixes up references in all of the copied links by calling . It passes as arguments both the original link data and the copied link data, as well as the newly copied from, to, and label nodes, if any.

remarks.para: This will iterate over all of the child elements of the container, calling on each one. If that function returns non-null, it calls on the new data and then adds it to the collection. It will then iterate again over all of the child elements of the root container, calling on each one. If that function returns non-null, it calls on the new data and then adds it to the collection.
All of the changes to this model are performed within a transaction.
This does not set the property to false. You may wish to do so, depending on your application requirements. You might also wish to clear the .

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.UniversalGraphLinksModel
member.summary: This is a universal model, handling all kinds of datatypes representing nodes, node keys, and links.

remarks.para: This assumes that each node or link can be a member of at most one subgraph node. Since it uses Object as the type for node data, this model class supports multiple instances of different (unrelated) types.
For reasons of both compile-time type checking and run-time efficiency, we recommend defining your own model class derived from .
This defines nested classes: DataCollection and CopyDictionary.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether all node data are also their own keys.
member.value: The default value is false. For this to be set to true, the type and the types must be the same.

remarks.para: This is used for model discovery. It is an optimization that avoids the use of an additional hash table mapping values to their data, and permits other optimizations as well. This can often be set to true when "references" to nodes are actually using .NET CLR references (i.e. "pointers") instead of values such as integer, strings, GUIDs et al.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphModel`2.MakeNodeKeyUnique(`0)
member.summary: This method is called when a duplicate key has been found.
member.returns: true to accept the data as a node after having made the key unique in the model; false to ignore this data.

remarks.para: This is used for model discovery. When a node data is added to the collection, checks for a duplicate key value. If it is a duplicate key, this method is called to either modify the node data to have a unique key, or to return false to avoid adding the data to this model. (However, the duplicate key node data will still be in the collection.)
This method is frequently overridden to implement the desired policy for your particular application model.
When the user copies selected nodes into a diagram, it is likely that this method will be called.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphModel`2.ClearUnresolvedReferences
member.summary: Forget all unresolved delayed or forward references.

remarks.para: The model may learn about node data in any order, so references to nodes may be unresolvable until later, perhaps never. Call this method to clear the internal table that keeps track of s that are not yet defined.
This is called when setting a number of property path properties, because a model property path change can completely alter the references each node data might be making.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphModel`2.CopyNode1(`0,Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphModel{`0,`1}.CopyDictionary)
member.summary: This is the first pass of copying node data, responsible for constructing a copy and copying most of its properties.

remarks.para: By default this handles ICloneable or serializable objects. But you may want to override this method to customize which properties get copied or how they are copied or to provide a faster implementation.

This does NOT ensure that the copied node data has a unique key. You must do that before adding it to the collection, either by overriding the data's Clone method, or by declaring the data Serializable (WPF), by overriding this method. Or you can override the method that is called when data is added to the collection of the model.

member.summary: This is the second pass of copying node data, responsible for fixing up references to other objects.
member.param: the original node data
the dictionary mapping original objects to copied objects
the copied node data
for convenience, the copied "parent" node data
for convenience, a list of newly copied member nodes
for convenience, a list of newly copied nodes that the new data is connected from
for convenience, a list of newly copied nodes that the new data is connected to

remarks.para: You will want to override this method if the node data should have any references to copied data. Otherwise the copied node will appear to have links to the original nodes, not to the copied nodes.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphModel`2.DataCollection
member.summary: This nested class is a serializable collection of node data.

remarks.para: This is used in various circumstances where there is a collection of node data, particularly for copying. If the node data is serializable, this collection can be serialized, which is useful when copying to the clipboard or pasting from it.
Although this nested type is not a generic class, it is parameterized by the NodeType and NodeKey type parameters of the containing generic model class. You should call to allocate an instance.
This collection class does not support separate link data.

member.summary: Add a copy of a node data to this model.

remarks.para: This is a convenience method that just calls .

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphModel`2.AddCollectionCopy(Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphModel{`0,`1}.DataCollection,Northwoods.GoXam.Model.GraphModel{`0,`1}.CopyDictionary)
member.summary: Copy existing node data and add to this model.
member.param: the collection of data to be copied
the used to keep track of copied objects; if null, the method will call , use it, and return it
member.returns: the updated copy dictionary, mapping original data to copied data

remarks.para: The primary purpose of this method is to perform a two-pass copy of a part of a diagram, and add the resulting data to this model.
Of course you can add data without copying them by calling or by just adding them directly to the .
This calls on the source model to allow it to extend the collection to include parts that it thinks should be in the collection.
Then it calls on this, the destination model, to allow it to prepopulate the if it wants to guide the copying process to control the sharing of references in the copied parts.

The first pass copies all of the nodes that are not already in the copy dictionary, by calling . If the call returns a node data, it is added to this model by calling and remembered in the copy dictionary, mapped to the original node data.

The second pass fixes up references in all of the copied nodes by calling . It passes as arguments both the original node data and the copied node data, as well as the newly copied group node, if any, and a list of member nodes.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.UniversalGraphModel
member.summary: This is a universal model, handling all kinds of datatypes representing nodes.

remarks.para: This assumes that each node can be a member of at most one subgraph node. Since it uses Object as the type for node data, this model class supports multiple instances of different (unrelated) types.
For reasons of both compile-time type checking and run-time efficiency, we recommend defining your own model class derived from .
This defines nested classes: DataCollection and CopyDictionary.

remarks.para: This is used for model discovery. When a node data is added to the collection, checks for a duplicate key value. If it is a duplicate key, this method is called to either modify the node data to have a unique key, or to return false to avoid adding the data to this model. (However, the duplicate key node data will still be in the collection.)
This method is frequently overridden to implement the desired policy for your particular application model.
When the user copies selected nodes into a diagram, it is likely that this method will be called.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.TreeModel`2.CopyNode1(`0,Northwoods.GoXam.Model.TreeModel{`0,`1}.CopyDictionary)
member.summary: This is the first pass of copying node data, responsible for constructing a copy and copying most of its properties.

remarks.para: By default this handles ICloneable or serializable objects. But you may want to override this method to customize which properties get copied or how they are copied or to provide a faster implementation.

This does NOT ensure that the copied node data has a unique key. You must do that before adding it to the collection, either by overriding the data's Clone method, by declaring the data Serializable (WPF), or by overriding this method. Or you can override the method that is called when data is added to the collection of the model.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.TreeModel`2.AddCollectionCopy(Northwoods.GoXam.Model.TreeModel{`0,`1}.DataCollection,Northwoods.GoXam.Model.TreeModel{`0,`1}.CopyDictionary)
member.summary: Copy existing node data and add to this model.
member.param: the collection of data to be copied
the used to keep track of copied objects; if null, the method will call , use it, and return it
member.returns: the updated copy dictionary, mapping original data to copied data

remarks.para: The primary purpose of this method is to perform a two-pass copy of a part of a diagram, and add the resulting data to this model.
Of course you can add data without copying them by calling or by just adding them directly to the .
This calls on the source model to allow it to extend the collection to include parts that it thinks should be in the collection.
Then it calls on this, the destination model, to allow it to prepopulate the if it wants to guide the copying process to control the sharing of references in the copied parts.

The first pass copies all of the nodes that are not already in the copy dictionary, by calling . If the call returns a node data, it is added to this model by calling and remembered in the copy dictionary, mapped to the original node data.

The second pass fixes up references in all of the copied nodes by calling . It passes as arguments both the original node data and the copied node data, as well as the newly copied tree-parent node, if any.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.UniversalTreeModel
member.summary: This is a universal model, handling all kinds of datatypes representing nodes.

remarks.para: There are no container nodes, nor are there link labels. Since it uses Object as the type for node data, this model class supports multiple instances of different (unrelated) types.
For reasons of both compile-time type checking and run-time efficiency, we recommend defining your own model class derived from .
This defines nested classes: DataCollection and CopyDictionary.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.UndoManager.MaximumEditCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of compound edits that this undo manager will remember.
member.value: If the value is negative, no limit is assumed. A new value of zero is treated as if the new value were one. The initial value is 999.

remarks.para: This property is useful in helping limit the memory consumption of typical application usage. But note that this only limits the number of compound edits, not the size of any individual , which may still have an unlimited number of s.
Decreasing this value will not necessarily remove any existing edits if there currently exist more edits in than the new value would allow.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.UndoManager.StartTransaction(System.String)
member.summary: Begin a transaction, where the changes are held by a .
member.returns: true if starting a top-level transaction
member.remarks:
Transactions can be nested:
StartTransaction returns true
StartTransaction returns false
CommitTransaction returns false
CommitTransaction returns true
Nested transactions will share the same compound edit as the top-level one. This will raise a event for each of the , with a hint of .

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Model.UndoManager.EndTransaction(System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: Stop the current transaction, either rolling it back or committing it.
member.param: true to terminate the transaction normally; false to abort it and rollback the existing edits
the internal locale-neutral name for the transaction
member.returns: true for a committed top-level transaction

remarks.para: If this call stops a top-level transaction, a value of false for just undoes and discards the information in the . If is true for a top-level transaction, we mark the complete, call , and add the resulting to the list of compound edits that this undo manager is recording.

Committing a transaction when there have been some undos without corresponding redos will throw away the compound edits holding changes that happened after the current state, before adding this new compound edit to the undo manager's list of edits.

This method raises a event for each of this undo manager's , with a hint of , and with a that is the that has been added to the list of . Similarly, if the transaction is aborted, either because is false or because there is no to commit, all of the get a Changed event. The values passed in the may all be null, however.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Palette
member.summary: The Palette control is a that holds parts that can be dragged to a .

remarks.para: It is commonplace to have a different and probably simpler node DataTemplate for s than for the destination s.

By default a palette uses a as its . That GridLayout defaults to sorting all of the nodes by the (attached) property. It also re-layouts automatically whenever the viewport size changes, because the size of the changes or because the scale changes.
The default style for a palette also makes it , and sets to be true, to permit drag-and-drop operations to start from this palette and to end on other diagrams.
