member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.PartManager
member.summary: This class handles the event for the 's and is responsible for creating and removing s and s for the data in the model.

remarks.para: Each has an instance of this class as its property. This class maintains a collection of all diagram and , as well as dictionaries mapping model data to s and s. You can find the for a model data object by calling and . Use when the model does not support separate link data objects.

If you want to add nodes programmatically, don't call ! You need to add node data to the model by calling . That will automatically update all diagrams that are using the model by calling , which will in turn call for you. Remember to wrap all changes to a model or to its data in a transaction.

Although this class inherits from FrameworkElement in order to support data binding, it is not really a FrameworkElement or UIElement! Please ignore all of the properties, methods, and events defined by FrameworkElement and UIElement.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.PartManager.OnModelChanged(Northwoods.GoXam.Model.ModelChangedEventArgs)
member.summary: This is called for each event of the .
member.param: the property gives a basic description of the change to the model

remarks.para: The implementation of this method and the methods that it calls should not modify the model.
Property changes to the model itself are conveyed by specific values, not by the general case.
For small changes such as the addition or removal of node data from the model, this calls the or method.
For changes in link relationships in the model, this calls , , , or .

For more wholescale changes, such as a change in the , this will call to discard all existing nodes and links and reconstruct them using the appropriate (and perhaps changed) data templates. For widespread changes only involving links, this will call .

This ignores property changes to model data, because those should be handled directly by data-bindings in the DataTemplate elements. The only exception is when is true and the PropertyName is "Points".

member.remarks: If you want to add a to the diagram, call . There is no guaranteed order in which the s are returned in this value.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.PartManager.NodesCount

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.PartManager.RebuildNodeElements
member.summary: Discard all existing s and s and then make new ones for all of model data and add them to the .

remarks.para: This deletes all existing s from the diagram and then calls and .
This tries to maintain the collection of after the parts have all been reconstructed.
The implementation of this method and the methods that it calls should not modify the model.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.PrintManager
member.summary: This class is responsible for printing a diagram.

remarks.para: Call the method to perform printing. If the area to be printed is large enough, it will print enough pages to cover the area. The sheets of paper may be taped together to produce a large drawing.

Although this class inherits from FrameworkElement in order to support data binding, it is not really a FrameworkElement or UIElement! Please ignore all of the properties, methods, and events defined by FrameworkElement and UIElement.

Normally this will print all of the s and s in the within the . You can specify what parts it prints by supplying the collection. You can also limit the area of the model that is printed by setting the property.

You can also control whether the 's Background or any background is printed, by setting the property. By default, only the grid is printed. If you want to have the grid and templates fill the whole page, set the property to include , for example: PageOptions="FullGridBackground".

The size on the page for the printed parts is governed by the property. You can set that property to zero to cause it to scale everything to fit on one page. Otherwise the number of pages that will be printed will depend on the area to be printed (determined by either the parts that are printed or the specified ) times the , as will fit in the size of each page minus the s.

You can print decorations on each page by specifying the and/or the . These templates are applied to each page, data-bound to an instance of describing that page. This makes it easy to customize the header or footer. For example:
<go:Diagram . . .> <go:Diagram.PrintManager> <go:PrintManager> <go:PrintManager.BackgroundTemplate> <DataTemplate> <go:SpotPanel> <TextBlock Text="Confidential" Foreground="LightGray" FontSize="50" RenderTransformOrigin="0.5 0.5"> <TextBlock.RenderTransform> <RotateTransform Angle="-45" /> </TextBlock.RenderTransform> </TextBlock> </go:SpotPanel> </DataTemplate> </go:PrintManager.BackgroundTemplate> </go:PrintManager> </go:Diagram.PrintManager> </go:Diagram>

You can see the definition of the standard in the Generic.XAML file that is in the docs subdirectory of the GoXam installation. It includes cut marks so that you can cut off the right sides and the bottoms of each of the pages that are not in the last column or the last row, allowing you to tape the sheets together to form a visually continuous diagram.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Spot
member.summary: A spot represents a relative point from (0,0) to (1,1) within the bounds of an element, plus an absolute offset.

remarks.para: A spot can represent a particular point (such as or new Spot(0.25, 0.25)), or a particular side (such as ) or multiple sides (such as ), or when equal to no particular point at all.

The and values denote the fractional distance of the spot point along the dimensions of the element's width and height. Zero is at the left or the top of the element; one is at the right or the bottom of the element. The values must be between 0 and 1. Values that are NaN are reserved for special spots such as or the spots that represent sides.

Once the point is determined by the and values within a particular bounding rectangle, the and values are added to determine the final point. The offset values may be negative. Negative offset values when the (X,Y) are near the left and/or top may result in a point that is outside of the bounds of the element. Positive offset values when the (X,Y) are near the right and/or bottom may also result in a point that is outside of the bounds of the element.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.Spot.None
member.summary: Use this value to indicate no particular spot -- code looking for a particular point on an element will need to do their own calculations to determine the desired point depending on the circumstances.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.Spot.Default
member.summary: Use this value to indicate that the real spot value is elsewhere.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Spot.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: Convert a string into a value.

remarks.para: The string can be up to four numbers separated by spaces. The first number is , the second number is , the third number is , the fourth number is . Missing numbers default to zero.
The string can also be any of the named special spot values, such as "None", "Center", "TopLeft", "TopSide", "LeftRightSides", "AllSides", or any other of the predefined field names that are spots.

For regular specific spots, this results in a string consisting of four numbers separated by spaces. The values of , , , and , are written in that order.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.SpotPanel
member.summary: This panel is useful for positioning child elements relative either to the bounds of a particular child or to a computed rectangle.

remarks.para: The child elements of a SpotPanel are positioned according the values of two attached properties: Spot and Alignment. Both property values are of type . Typically each child will at least specify a value for the Spot attached property, and will also specify a value for Alignment for minor adjustments in the position.

The value of specifies a point in a rectangle where the element should be positioned. The value of specifies what point of the element should be positioned at the spot point of the rectangle. Both properties default to -- the center of the element is centered inside the rectangle. (This panel ignores the FrameworkElement.HorizontalAlignment and VerticalAlignment properties.)

The rectangle used for determining spot points is given by the bounds of the child element of the panel that has the set to true. If there is no such element, the value of is used instead. By default will return the desired size of the first child. However, the class overrides the method to return values unrelated to any of this panel's children.

Here's an example of a SpotPanel as a DataTemplate for a node. This places text at various points around the main Rectangle.
<go:SpotPanel go:Node.Resizable="True" go:Node.SelectionElementName="Rectangle"> <Rectangle x:Name="Rectangle" go:SpotPanel.Main="True" Stroke="Black" StrokeThickness="1" Width="100" Height="100" /> <TextBlock go:SpotPanel.Spot="TopLeft" go:SpotPanel.Alignment="TopLeft" Text="inside" /> <TextBlock go:SpotPanel.Spot="TopLeft" go:SpotPanel.Alignment="BottomLeft" Text="atop" /> <TextBlock go:SpotPanel.Spot="TopLeft" go:SpotPanel.Alignment="TopRight" Text="aside" /> <TextBlock go:SpotPanel.Spot="Center" go:SpotPanel.Alignment="Center" Text="center" /> <TextBlock go:SpotPanel.Spot="1 0.7 -20 0" Text="-20" /> <TextBlock go:SpotPanel.Spot="1 0.7 0 0" Text="0" /> <TextBlock go:SpotPanel.Spot="1 0.7 20 0" Text="+20" /> </go:SpotPanel>
A SpotPanel has a special usage when it is the of an and there is no child that is the "Main" child -- returns the size of the .

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Layer
member.summary: A Layer is a collection of s or s that are to be displayed in front of or behind the parts in other layers.

remarks.para: Each layer can only be a child of a -- they cannot be nested. There are two classes inheriting from this abstract Layer class: and , which hold only nodes or only links, respectively.
Each layer has an property that is used to identify the layer in the amongst multiple layers of the same type.

There are many properties, named "Allow...", that control what operations the user may perform on the parts held by this layer. These correspond to the same named properties on that govern the behavior for all parts in all layers. Furthermore for some of these properties there are corresponding properties on , named "...able", that govern the behavior for that individual part. For example, the property corresponds to and to the property . The predicate is false if any of these properties is false.
You may not apply any transforms to a Layer; that is reserved to GoXam for future use.

member.summary: Add a to this layer.

remarks.para: This is infrequently called. You normally should set the part's in order to specify or change the layer that a part will be in.

This does not modify the model. It just changes the layer that the node is in, thereby making the node eligible to be seen by the user. If it had been part of another layer, it is removed from that other layer first.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkPanel
member.summary: A LinkPanel is a Panel used to position and orient elements along the route of a .

remarks.para: The simplest is implemented with a DataTemplate that consists of a Shape that is the stroke (a line) connecting one node with another. In WPF that is normally an instance of LinkShape; Such a link cannot have any arrowheads or text labels or other decorations. Furthermore you cannot connect any link to or from the link itself, nor can any link labels be selectable or manipulable as separate objects.

However, most s are implemented as DataTemplates consisting of s. The principal child element of a LinkPanel is normally a LinkShape that has the x:Name of "Path" and that has the attached property set to true. The panel arranges the other child elements along the 's according to various attached properties.
To make it easy to implement common arrowheads, you can set the and/or attached properties on a Path element.
At the current time a LinkPanel or LinkShape/Path must be the root visual element of a .

Here is a simple DataTemplate for a that has an arrowhead:
<DataTemplate x:Key="ExampleLinkTemplate"> <go:LinkPanel go:Link.SelectionElementName="Path" go:Link.SelectionAdorned="True" > <go:LinkShape x:Name="Path" Stroke="Black" StrokeThickness="1" /> <Path Fill="Black" go:LinkPanel.ToArrow="Standard" /> </go:LinkPanel> </DataTemplate>

A LinkPanel may have multiple children (LinkShape for which go:LinkPanel.IsLinkShape="True". One of them must be the primary link path, with the x:Name of "Path"; this is what will be returned by the property. All of rest will get the same route geometry as the primary . This makes it easy to implement gradient-like effects by using multiple link shapes of different colors:
<go:LinkPanel . . .> <go:LinkShape StrokeThickness="7" Stroke="DarkBlue" /> <go:LinkShape StrokeThickness="5" Stroke="Blue" /> <go:LinkShape StrokeThickness="3" Stroke="LightBlue" /> <go:LinkShape x:Name="Path" StrokeThickness="1" Stroke="White" /> . . . </go:LinkPanel>
By default each LinkPanel sets UseLayoutRounding to false, except that it is set to true when used inside an .

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkPanel.GetIndex(System.Windows.DependencyObject)
member.summary: Gets an element's segment index along the link's route.
member.param: a child element of a

returns.para: Zero identifies the segment closest to the "from" end of the route. Positive values identify segments further along the route. Negative values identify segments starting at the "to" end of the route; -1 is the last segment, -2 is the next to last, etc.
If the index is not specified for an element, the will arrange it to be at the 's .

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkPanel.FractionProperty
member.summary: Identifies the Fraction attached dependency property.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkPanel.GetFraction(System.Windows.DependencyObject)
member.summary: Gets the fractional distance along a segment at which the element should be positioned.
member.param: a child element of a
member.returns: The default value is zero. For negative indexes, the fraction increases from zero to one as the point moves from the "to" end towards the "from" end.
member.remarks: The fraction is not used when the value is not a valid point/segment in the route.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkPanel.SetFraction(System.Windows.DependencyObject,System.Double)
member.summary: Sets the fractional distance along a segment at which the element should be positioned.
member.param: a child element of a

The fraction should be between zero and one, inclusive. For non-negative indexes, the fraction increases from zero to one as the point moves from the "from" end toward the "to" end. For negative indexes, the fraction increases from zero to one as the point moves from the "to" end towards the "from" end.
member.remarks: The fraction is not used when the value is not a valid point/segment in the route.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkPanel.OffsetProperty
member.summary: Identifies the Offset attached dependency property.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkPanel.GetOffset(System.Windows.DependencyObject)
member.summary: Gets the distances from the fractional point of a link segment at which the element should be positioned.
member.param: a child element of a
member.returns: The default value is (0, 0). The offset distances are in model coordinates. The offset is rotated to the angle of the link segment. Positive X values result in the element being positioned farther along the link segment; negative values are closer. Positive Y values result in the element being positioned away from the link segment on the right side of the path; negative values go toward the left side.

The offset distances are in model coordinates. The offset is rotated to the angle of the link segment. Positive X values result in the element being positioned farther along the link segment; negative values are closer. Positive Y values result in the element being positioned away from the link segment on the right side of the path; negative values go toward the left side.

Setting the ToArrowProperty on multiple Paths that are children of the same LinkPanel will result in overlap of the Path.Data geometries.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.LabelOrientation
member.summary: This enumeration governs if and how a 's child element or label node is rotated to be oriented along the of a .

remarks.para: These values are supplied by the attached property on each link panel child element or label node. You can also override for more flexibility in controlling the angle of an element.
The "Upright" values are typically only used when the element contains text.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LabelOrientation.None
member.summary: The element is never rotated -- the angle is always zero.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LabelOrientation.Along
member.summary: The element's angle is always the same as the angle of the link's route at the segment where the element is attached. The element is turned to have the same angle as the route. Use this orientation for arrow heads.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LabelOrientation.Plus90
member.summary: The element's angle is always 90 degrees more than the angle of the link's route at the segment where the element is attached. The element is turned clockwise to be perpendicular to the route.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LabelOrientation.Minus90
member.summary: The element's angle is always 90 degrees less than the angle of the link's route at the segment where the element is attached. The element is turned counter-clockwise to be perpendicular to the route.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LabelOrientation.Opposite
member.summary: The element's angle is always 180 degrees opposite from the angle of the link's route at the segment where the element is attached.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LabelOrientation.Upright
member.summary: The element's angle always follows the angle of the link's route at the segment where the element is attached, but is never upside down. The element is turned to have the same angle as the route, just like . This is typically only used for elements that contain text.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LabelOrientation.Plus90Upright
member.summary: The element's angle is always 90 degrees more than the angle of the link's route at the segment where the element is attached, but is never upside down. The element is turned clockwise to be perpendicular to the route, just like . This is typically only used for elements that contain text.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LabelOrientation.Minus90Upright
member.summary: The element's angle is always 90 degrees less than the angle of the link's route at the segment where the element is attached, but is never upside down. The element is turned counter-clockwise to be perpendicular to the route, just like . This is typically only used for elements that contain text.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LabelOrientation.Upright45
member.summary: The element's angle always follows the angle of the link's route at the segment where the element is attached, but is never upside down and is never angled more than +/- 45 degrees. When the route's angle is within 45 degrees of vertical (90 or 270 degrees), the element's angle is set to zero. This is typically only used for elements that contain text.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkPanelImplementation
member.summary: This enumeration describes the kinds of principal elements a uses to render the route of a .
member.remarks: This is the type of the property.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkPanelImplementation.Path
member.summary: The normal case where the route is shown as a stroked open Shape that is a possibly multi-segment or curved line. For this case the value of will be a LinkShape.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkPanelImplementation.Fixed
member.summary: The link is shown as any rotated fixed-size UIElement.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkPanelImplementation.Stretch
member.summary: The link is shown as any rotated UIElement, but its width is arranged to be stretched to reach the distance between the end points of the route.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.DiagramPanel
member.summary: The DiagramPanel is the central class of a , holding all of the s of s, responsible for translation (scrolling) and scaling (zooming) and alignment, keeping track of the diagram's bounds, and having various hit-testing methods used to search the diagram for particular elements.

remarks.para: A DiagramPanel must be in the ControlTemplate of a . Both the and the DiagramPanel are useless without each other.

Because DiagramPanel is a Panel, you can define the layers of this panel in XAML by placing them nested within the definition of the <DiagramPanel> element. If you do not define any layers explicitly, the method will create the standard nine layers: "Background" nodes and links, default ("") nodes and links, "Foreground" nodes and links, "Tool" nodes and links, and "Adornment" nodes.
This class is also responsible for mouse input. It redirects mouse events to the 's .
You may not apply any transforms to a ; that is reserved for GoXam's use. This panel's Background is also reserved for GoXam's use.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.DiagramPanel.FixedBounds
member.summary: Gets or sets a fixed bounding rectangle to be returned by .
member.value: By default this has Double.NaN values, meaning that should actually compute the union of all of the parts in the diagram. If all X/Y/Width/Height values are actual numbers, this value is returned by .

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.DiagramPanel.PositionProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.DiagramPanel.Position
member.summary: Gets or sets the point, in model coordinates, shown at the top-left corner of this panel.
member.value: The default value is (0,0). For example, increasing the X value of this property will cause all of the parts to appear farther to the left; some parts that are located at X coordinates just less than the new X value will "disappear" off-screen. This property changes as the user scrolls in any direction.
member.remarks: The value may be limited by the size and extent of the , as tries to implement policies that limit how far one may scroll.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.DiagramPanel.ScaleProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.DiagramPanel.Scale
member.summary: Gets or sets the scale factor at which everything is rendered.
member.value: The default value is 1.0 -- one unit in model coordinates is the same size as a device-independent-pixel. Values larger than 1.0 result in parts that appear larger, as if zooming into the diagram. Values smaller than 1.0 make everything appear smaller, as if zooming out of the diagram. Any new value must be a number larger than zero.
member.remarks: Changing the scale may also result in a change in , as tries to keep the diagram's parts aligned in the panel.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.DiagramPanel.MinimumScaleProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.DiagramPanel.MinimumScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the smallest value greater than zero that may take.
member.value: The default value is 0.0001. Values must be larger than zero and no greater than one. This property is only used to limit the range of new values in the setter.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.DiagramPanel.MaximumScaleProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.DiagramPanel.MaximumScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the largest value that may take.
member.value: The default value is 100.0. Values must be no less than one. This property is only used to limit the range of new values in the setter.

member.summary: Gets or sets the apparent focus point used when zooming in or out.
member.value: This value is in element coordinates, not in model coordinates. The default value is (NaN, NaN), which means the actual zoom point used depends on the and properties.
member.remarks: This is used by . It is temporarily set by so that the user can zoom into a diagram at the mouse point when rotating the mouse wheel with the Control key modifier.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.DiagramPanel.AutoScrollRegionProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.DiagramPanel.AutoScrollRegion
member.summary: Gets or sets the margin in the panel where a mouse drag will automatically cause the view to scroll.
member.value: The Thickness value defaults to 16,16,16,16.
member.remarks: When the mouse drag point is within this region on the left or right sides, the view will automatically scroll horizontally in that direction. When the point is within the region on the top or bottom, the view will automatically scroll vertically in that direction. You can specify a distance of zero to disable autoscrolling in a direction; a value of 0,0,0,0 turns off autoscrolling altogether.

member.value: The time is in milliseconds. The default is 33 milliseconds. The value must not be negative.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.DiagramPanel.AutoScrollDelayProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.DiagramPanel.AutoScrollDelay
member.summary: Gets or sets how long to wait before autoscrolling.
member.value: The time is in milliseconds. The default is 1000 (one second). The value must not be negative.
member.remarks: This is helpful in avoiding autoscrolling when the user is dragging something into the view and doesn't yet intend to autoscroll.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.DiagramPanel.DoAutoScroll(System.Windows.Point)
member.summary: Start or continue automatically scrolling the view during a mouse drag.
member.param: the current mouse point, in model coordinates

remarks.para: As soon returns a new value, this method starts a Timer that waits for milliseconds. After waiting, it repeatedly sets to the latest value, until the position does not change (presumably because the 's last mouse point is no longer in the autoscroll margin). Setting this view's occurs each milliseconds.
This method is normally called by those tools that want to support auto-scrolling during a mouse move, such as dragging. The timer is stopped when the mouse leaves this view.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.DiagramPanel.StopAutoScroll
member.summary: Stop any ongoing auto-scroll action.
member.remarks: This stops the Timer used to get repeating events to consider scrolling.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.DiagramPanel.ComputeAutoScrollPosition(System.Windows.Point)
member.summary: This method is called to determine the next position in the document for this view, given a point at which the user is dragging the mouse.
member.param: The mouse point, in control coordinates.
member.value: The return value is in model coordinates.
member.remarks: This uses the , , and properties to calculate a new . The closer the point is to the edge of the view, the larger a multiple of the or is used as a scroll step in that direction.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.DiagramPanel.InitializeLayers
member.summary: If there are no s in this panel's collection of Children, create the standard set of layers.
member.remarks: This creates the following pairs of s and s, with s of: "Background", default (""), "Foreground", and "Tool". Finally it creates and adds a that is the , in front of all of the other layers, for holding selection handles and tool handles. The "Tool" layers and are layers holding temporary objects, so this sets their property to true.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.DiagramPanel.PerformGesture(Northwoods.GoXam.GestureModifiers,Northwoods.GoXam.Gesture,System.Windows.Point,System.Windows.Point,Northwoods.GoXam.Diagram)
member.summary: Simulate some mouse events.
member.param: a value, some combination of , , and
a value, typically ; a value of does nothing
the Point in model coordinates for the mouse down event; this value must be within the
the Point in model coordinates for the mouse up event; this value must be within the

The where the mouse up occurs. If this is different from this panel's , a simulated drag-and-drop will occur. (This does not use real Windows drag-and-drop in WPF.) This may be null to use this panel's diagram, thus keeping the whole gesture within this one diagram.

remarks.para: This method can have the same effect as several calls to "OnMouse..." methods, without requiring the use of any MouseEventArgs, MouseButtonEventArgs, or MouseWheelEventArgs. For the mouse double click gestures, such as , this is equivalent to a mouse down, mouse up, mouse down, and a mouse up. For the mouse button gestures, such as , this is equivalent to a mouse down, two mouse moves if is different than , and a mouse up. For the mouse wheel gestures, such as , this is equivalent to a mouse wheel turn.
In all cases the Points are in model coordinates, not in FrameworkElement coordinates. The down and up points must be within the current .

If you pass a different diagram as the argument instead of null, this simulates a drag-and-drop from this diagram to that other diagram. Even in WPF, the drag-and-drop will be simulated, rather than using real Windows drag-and-drop, as it would if it did not have permission. The various methods that take DragEventArgs are not called. Supplying a different diagram is not supported for wheel and double-click gestures.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.GroupPanel
member.summary: An auto-resizing that always surrounds its 's plus some .

remarks.para: Note that the member nodes of a group are NOT children of this panel. Typically only decorative elements and ports are part of a GroupPanel.
A node template representing a group, if it contains a GroupPanel, must name that GroupPanel as the node's , resulting in referring to that panel.

For example, the following DataTemplate for s results in a thick border around the group's member nodes with some text above the top-left corner of the border and a port on each side in the middle of the border.
<DataTemplate x:Key="ExampleGroupTemplate"> <StackPanel go:Node.LocationElementName="GroupPanel"> <TextBlock Text="{Binding Path=Data.Name}" /> <Border BorderBrush="Gray" BorderThickness="6" CornerRadius="5" Margin="0"> <go:GroupPanel x:Name="GroupPanel" Padding="10" > <Path go:SpotPanel.Spot="0 0.5 -3 0" Data="M0 0 L6 3 L 0 6 Z" Fill="Blue" Width="6" Height="6" go:Node.PortId="input" go:Node.LinkableTo="True" /> <Path go:SpotPanel.Spot="1 0.5 3 0" Data="M0 0 L6 3 L 0 6 Z" Fill="Green" Width="6" Height="6" go:Node.PortId="output" go:Node.LinkableFrom="True" /> </go:GroupPanel> </Border> </StackPanel> </DataTemplate>

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Part
member.summary: A Part is an item in a 's 's , corresponding to data representing a node or a link.

remarks.para: There are two classes inheriting from this abstract class: and .

Each Part can only be a child element of a : either a or a . Parts cannot be nested in the visual tree. However, a subclass of node, , supports the logical nesting of nodes (and links) as members of a group. You can specify which layer a part should be in by setting its property.

A Part is typically created by the 's in response to the presence or addition of some data to the diagram's . The part manager creates the node or link, sets its Content property to the data (indirectly) and its ContentTemplate property to a DataTemplate based on the type of part and the part's . The FrameworkElement that results from the application of the template to the data is accessible as the property.
Each part has a property that describes its position and size in model coordinates. This property is read-only. One can change the bounds of a by setting its or property.
A part can be selected or de-selected by setting its property.

Most of the properties pertinent to parts are attached dependency properties rather than regular dependency properties. Many are only to be used on the , not on the part itself nor on nested elements in the part's visual tree. The reason for using attached properties is to make it easier to data bind those properties in the data template.

An example is the . Consider the following data template for nodes:
<DataTemplate x:Key="ExampleTemplate"> <Border Background="White" BorderBrush="Blue" BorderThickness="2" CornerRadius="3" Padding="2,0,2,0" go:Node.LayerName="{Binding Path=Data.LayerName}"> <TextBlock Text="{Binding Path=Data.Name}" /> </Border> </DataTemplate>
The example assumes that the node data to which each node is bound has at least two properties: one named "Name" holding the text to be displayed, and one named "LayerName" specifying the name of the that the node should be in. Note that setting the attribute for the layer name refers to the attached property qualified by the class name ("Node" in this case, in the XMLNS namespace referenced by "go").

The CLR property of gets and sets the value of the on the part's . Please be aware that such property getters will just return the default value for the property when the data template has not yet been applied, as will be the case when is null. Such property setters will try applying the template if needed before actually setting the attached property on the .

Note that the data binding goes indirectly through a property named "Data":
<TextBlock Text="{Binding Path=Data.Name}" />
This is because the part's Content is not the data itself but a simple data structure that includes the data as its property. The other property refers to the itself. This permits bindings such as:
<DataTrigger Binding="{Binding Path=Part.IsSelected}" Value="True" > <Setter Property="Border.BorderBrush" Value="Red" /> <Setter Property="go:Node.LayerName" Value="Foreground" /> </DataTrigger>
This results in the border's brush changing color when the node is selected, and in the node being moved to the foreground layer when it is selected. (This requires corresponding changes to the Border element, since the BorderBrush and go:Node.LayerName properties should not be set locally if they want to be modified in a style trigger.)

There are many properties, named "...able", that control what operations the user may perform on this part. These properties correspond to the same named properties on and that govern the behavior for all parts in all layers or for all parts in the given layer. For example, the property corresponds to the properties and .
For each of these "ability" properties there is a corresponding "Can..." predicate. For example, the predicate is false if any of the three previously named properties is false.

As previously mentioned, supports the notion of selected parts. The part class also supports showing visual objects for a part when it gets selected. These visuals are typically used to show that the part is selected ("selection handles") or are used to allow the user to manipulate or modify the part with a tool ("tool handles"). These handles are the visual elements of nodes. The method is responsible for showing or hiding adornments, normally depending on whether the part is selected.

When the (attached) property is true, a selected part automatically gets an node created for it. Such a node gets a ContentTemplate property that is the value of . (If the value is null, a default selection adornment template is used.) If the node is bound to data, the adornment is also bound to the same data.

Tool handles are shown for those tools that need it. The process of updating adornments for a part will ask each mode-less tool to . Most tools might not need special tool handles. But, for example, naturally will want to create an adornment with eight resize handles positioned at the corners and at the middles of the sides of the selected node's visual element, if the node has returning true.

However one does not always want the whole part to get the selection handle and any tool handles. Sometimes one wants to emphasize selection by highlighting a particular element within the part's visual tree. This can be achieved by setting the property, and making sure the desired element has the same x:Name attribute value. For example, the following node template causes resize handles to appear surrounding the Rectangle element, not around the whole node.
<DataTemplate x:Key="ExampleTemplate"> <StackPanel go:Node.Resizable="True" go:Node.SelectionElementName="myIcon"> <Rectangle x:Name="myIcon" Width="30" Height="30" Fill="LightSalmon" Stroke="Maroon" StrokeThickness="2" /> <TextBlock Text="{Binding Path=Data.Name}" HorizontalAlignment="Center" /> </StackPanel> </DataTemplate>
There are some methods for finding and examining particular elements in the part's visual tree: , , , , , and .
There are other methods and properties for looking at the relationships between parts: , , , , and .
You may not apply any transforms to a Part; that is reserved to GoXam for future use.

member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Part.Category
member.summary: Gets a string identifying the kind of or or or the purpose of the .

value.para: The default value is an empty string. You cannot change this value once the Part has been added to a Diagram.

If you want to replace the DataTemplate used by a Part, you would normally set the Category property of your bound data. This would be reflected via the model in the , which handles by removing the Node from the Diagram and then adding it back again. The same is true for Links when .
But if you are not using a Category property on your data, because you have overridden or , you will need to call and yourself.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Part.IsSelected
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this part is selected.
member.value: The default value is false. Setting this property to true will cause this part to be added to the diagram's collection. Setting this property to false will cause this part to be removed from that collection.
member.remarks: If is false, one cannot set this property to true. Also, the number of selected parts is limited by the value of , so this part cannot be selected if that would violate that limit.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Part.Visible
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user may see or pick this part.
member.value: The default value is true. The value is actually stored on the . One normally sets it by setting or data-binding the attached property on the root element of the DataTemplate.

remarks.para: Setting this property also sets the Part.Visibility property to either Visibility.Visible or Visibility.Collapsed.

This dependency property is set by methods for collapsing/expanding subtrees, by methods for collapsing/expanding subgraphs, and by the as the model changes. Therefore one-way data-bindings of this attached dependency property to updated source properties may not get updated values when there are collapsed subtrees or collapsed subgraphs.

Caution: because the UIElement.Visibility of the may be set independently of this property, the value of this property may not reflect the value of Part.Visibility. This property is most useful in data templates for setting the initial value of Visibility for the part.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Node
member.summary: A Node is a to which s may connect and which may be a member of a .

remarks.para: Each Node has a property. By default this is the same as the X,Y position. However, you can set the property, whereas is a read-only property.

Furthermore, the "location" need not be the same as the top-left point of the "bounds". Often there is a particular FrameworkElement in the node that is the featured element, and the "location" for the node is actually a point within that element. You can specify which element provides the node's location by setting the property. By default the element name is the empty string, meaning to use the visual element of the node. You can specify which point on that element is the actual location point by setting the property. By default the location spot is , meaning the top-left point of the location element. Therefore, the combination of the two default location-specifying properties result in the location of a node to be the top-left point of the bounds of the whole node, the same as the position of the . But it is moderately common to specify a particular shape or image as the location element name, and it is fairly common to use as the location spot.

The property is a CLR property implemented using the attached dependency property on the node's . The reason that most of the node "properties" are implemented as attached dependency properties rather than regular CLR properties is that it allows for those property values to be data-bound. It is commonplace to specify the location using a data binding:
<DataTemplate x:Key="MyNodeTemplate"> <Border ... go:Node.Location="{Binding Path=Data.Location, Mode=TwoWay}"> ... </Border> </DataTemplate>
This data-binds the node's location with a property on the node data named "Location". Data binding not only keeps FrameworkElement properties in synch with data properties, but also helps support a model-view architecture and undo/redo.
The and properties help limit how far a node may be dragged.
The property sets the angle of the node's .

The most common relationship supported by nodes is a node-to-node link relationship. There are a number of properties that return collections of Nodes that a given node is connected with, and there are a number of properties that return collections of s that a given node connects with to other nodes. These properties are: , , , , , and .
Creating new links is achieved by adding or modifying data in the diagram's model. The precise methods depend on whether the model is an or an or an .

Nodes also support the ability to provide logical and physical distinctions in the connection points that links use at a node, if the diagram's model supports it. These connections points are called "ports". Some models assume that there is only one port per node. By default that will be the node's . However, one can set the attached property on any visual element to cause that FrameworkElement to be treated as a "port". In the case of a single port for a node, you should set the PortId as an empty string:
... <... ... go:Node.PortId="" ... > ...
You can get the FrameworkElement that is the default (single) port using the property.

When a node has multiple ports, i.e. multiple FrameworkElements acting as separate connection points for links, you should set each port's PortId to a string value that is unique for the node. When there may be multiple ports on a node, you can get a collection of FrameworkElements representing ports using the property. Use the method to find a particular port element by name. There are also methods for finding the collection of nodes or of links that are connected to a particular port element.

There are also several attached properties that can be set to control how links connect to that FrameworkElement. These include: , , , . There are also some attached properties that control whether users may create new links connecting to a port: , , , , and .

Nodes also support the notion of group membership for models that implement . The property returns the that a node is a member of, or null if there is no container group for that node. Changing the group membership of a node requires modifying the diagram's model.
The Node class also supports the notion of expanding and collapsing a subtree starting at a given node. There are two attached properties, and , that can be data-bound, as well as two methods, and .
You may not apply any transforms to a Node; that is reserved to GoXam for future use.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Node.Location
member.summary: Gets or sets the position of this node based on its .
member.value: The Point is in model coordinates. The value is related to . It may have a different value than depending on the values of and . The value is actually stored on the . One normally sets it by setting or data-binding the attached property on the root element of the DataTemplate.

remarks.para: It is common to set the to , so that the location of the node is always the coordinates of the center point of the . The always refers to the top-left corner point of the . Setting the will also update this .

Grid snapping, for example, will normally locate node Locations to be on grid points. (But you can change that by setting .) By setting the node's to be the center of one of the node's elements, by default the whole node, the element will be centered at the location.
The and also operate on the node's location, not its position.
However, the method takes a position, not a location.
This attached dependency property is set by various tools and layouts. Therefore one-way data-bindings of this attached dependency property to changing source properties may not get updated values.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Node.ZOrder
member.summary: Gets or sets the Z-ordering position of this node within its layer.

value.para: Within the same layer, nodes with larger ZOrder values are placed in front of nodes with smaller ZOrder values. When the value is NaN the ordering is not specified. The default value is NaN. The value is actually stored on the . One normally sets it by setting or data-binding the attached property on the root element of the DataTemplate.

When a has a ZOrder value of NaN, it is automatically placed behind its member nodes and links that also have no ZOrder. Such automatic ordering is not guaranteed if any nodes including the groups have a numeric ZOrder. If you do want to specify the ZOrder of nodes, you should also specify the ZOrder of their containing groups.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Node.RotationAngle
member.summary: Gets or sets the angle of the node's , in degrees.
member.value: The default value is 0.0 degrees. The value is actually stored on the . One normally sets it by setting or data-binding the attached property on the root element of the DataTemplate.

remarks.para: Angles start with zero being rightwards, in the direction of the positive X axis, and increase clockwise. 90 degrees, for example, goes downwards, in the direction of the positive Y axis.
It is the that is rotated, not necessarily the whole node. Often one wants to rotate the principal element(s) of the node, but not the text or other decorations.

You can enable user-controlled rotation of nodes by setting to true. That makes use of the , which may set this dependency property. Therefore one-way data-bindings of this attached dependency property to updated source properties may not get updated values when this property has been set.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Node.FindPort(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Find the FrameworkElement in this node whose Node.PortId attached property matches a given port parameter value.
member.param: This treats null as an empty string. The method returns the element whose value equals that string. If there is no such child element, it searches for an element whose value is the empty string. Finally, when failing to find a port with either the given name or the empty string, this method returns the root visual element for the node.
member.returns: a FrameworkElement, or null if no matching element is found

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Node.CollapseTree
member.summary: Make not visible each child node and the link connecting with the child node, and recursively collapse each child node.

remarks.para: Links are assumed to go from the parent node to the children nodes, unless is set to "Source".
This also calls to set that attached property, and to remember whether a tree child node had been expanded, to support data binding the state of the tree node.
This operation is performed within a "Collapse Tree" transaction.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Node.ExpandTree
member.summary: Make visible each child node and the link to the child node, and perhaps recursively expand their nodes.

remarks.para: Links are assumed to go from the parent node to the children nodes, unless is set to "Source".
This will expand a tree child node only if its was true.
This also calls to set that attached property, and if appropriate , to support data binding whether the tree is expanded.
This operation is performed within an "Expand Tree" transaction.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Group
member.summary: A Group is a that may logically contain other s and s.

remarks.para: You can get a collection of member nodes using the property. You can get a collection of member links using the property. Changing group membership requires modifying the diagram's model.
The member nodes and links are NOT visual children of this group. Instead they are direct visual children of a , just as this group is.

If one expects that the rendering of a group should grow and shrink based on the sizes and positions of its member nodes, the 's should make use of a . The property finds this panel for you. If there is a , it must be named and referred to by the .
This class also supports the notion of expanding/collapsing. There are two attached properties, and , that can be data-bound, as well as two methods, and .
Each group can have its own to govern how the member nodes and links are laid out, independently of the 's .
You may not apply any transforms to a Group; that is reserved to GoXam for future use.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Group.GroupPanel
member.summary: Gets the representing the group's member nodes and links.
member.value: This will be null if this group does not use a .

remarks.para: This group's member s and s are not visual children of this group. However, if there is a in the group's visual tree, it will be measured and arranged to have the same bounds as the collection of member nodes.
The location of the is always the location of its , if it has one. If there is a , it must be named and referred to as the for the group.

member.param: a new in model coordinates; not a new
whether the movement is animated by the diagram's
member.remarks: This uses the diagram's by calling its method in order to respect grid snapping and to try to avoid rerouting links. Currently, member nodes and links are not moved with animation.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Link
member.summary: A Link is a that represents a relationship between s.

remarks.para: A link connects the to the .

The rendering of a link is determined by the 's . This DataTemplate may be a simple LinkShape. However it is usually a , which supports child elements that act as arrowheads or text labels or other decoration on the link.

A link may also have a . In this case there is a separate that is associated with the link. The node's property will be true. It is usually positioned at the mid-point of the link. It supports its own link connections and may be independently selected or moved. The label node may be a , in which case all of its member nodes are link label nodes that are positioned by the .
You may not apply any transforms to a Link; that is reserved to GoXam for future use.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.DropOntoBehavior.None
member.summary: Don't do anything else besides the standard result of moving or copying the selection. This is the default value for .

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.DropOntoBehavior.AddsToGroup
member.summary: If the drop occurs on a , and if the group can accept having the selected nodes and links added as new members, then add them to that group. This is only effective if is true.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.DropOntoBehavior.AddsLinkFromNode
member.summary: If the drop occurs on a , new links are created from the dropped-onto node to each selected dropped node. This does not draw new links to dropped nodes that were members of dropped groups (i.e. members of selected groups). This is only effective if is true.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.DropOntoBehavior.AddsLinkToNode
member.summary: If the drop occurs on a , new links are created from the each selected dropped node to the dropped-onto node. This does not draw new links from dropped nodes that were members of dropped groups (i.e. members of selected groups). This is only effective if is true.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.DropOntoBehavior.SplicesIntoLink
member.summary: If the drop occurs on a , each selected dropped node is connected by a link from the original link's and by a link to the original link's , and the original link is removed. This is only effective if is true.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Route
member.summary: A Route is an object associated with a that computes and remembers the set of points that the link should follow to connect two nodes.

remarks.para:
The only use of a in XAML is as the value of the attached property:
<DataTemplate x:Key="MyLinkTemplate"> <go:LinkPanel go:Link.SelectionElementName="Path" go:Part.SelectionAdorned="True"> <go:Link.Route> <go:Route Routing="Orthogonal" Corner="10" RelinkableFrom="True" RelinkableTo="True" /> </go:Link.Route> <go:LinkShape x:Name="Path" Stroke="Black" StrokeThickness="1" /> <Path Fill="Black" go:LinkPanel.ToArrow="Standard" /> </go:LinkPanel> </DataTemplate>

Although this class inherits from FrameworkElement in order to support data binding, it is not really a FrameworkElement or UIElement! Please ignore all of the properties, methods, and events defined by FrameworkElement and UIElement.

member.remarks: The value for this property cannot exceed the length of the first segment of the Route. member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Route.Corner
member.summary: Gets or sets how rounded the corners are for adjacent line segments when the is , , or and the two line segments are orthogonal to each other.
member.value: This describes the maximum radius of rounded corners, in model coordinates. This defaults to 0.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Route.Orthogonal
member.summary: Gets whether the segments of the link are always horizontal or vertical.
member.remarks: You can change the value of this property by setting . This property primarily controls the behavior of , to position the points of the stroke so that straight line segments will be horizontal or vertical. You can have a link drawn with only horizontal and vertical segments if the link's curve is , , or . If the curve is , some of the orthogonally positioned points act as control points to help form the curve. The orthogonal algorithm adds two segments to the normal three segments so that it is possible to connect two ports using only orthogonal lines.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.Route.RoutingProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Route.Routing
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the link's path tries to avoid other nodes.
member.value: This defaults to .
member.remarks: Setting this property to or is not recommended when the is . Changing this property will eventually result in a call to .

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.Route.SmoothnessProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.GoXam.Route.Smoothness
member.summary: Gets or sets how far control points are from the points of the Route when Routing is and Curve is .
member.value: This defaults to 0.5.
member.remarks: Values of this property typically fall in the range of 0.0 to 1.0. A value of 0.0 indicates that the control points of the curve are at the end points, which will result in straight line segments. A value of 1.0 indicates that the control points are one-third of the link's length away from the end point along the direction of the link, and the same distance away in a perpendicular direction. The distance scales linearly with the value of this property, even with negative values and values greater than 1.0.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkCurve
member.summary: This enumeration defines how a path is drawn through a 's points.
member.remarks: This is used as the value of .

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkCurve.None
member.summary: Straight line segments between the 's points.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkCurve.JumpOver
member.summary: Straight line segments that also hop over other orthogonal link segments that it crosses. is similar. (Only applies when the route is orthogonal.)

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkCurve.Bezier
member.summary: A Bezier curve, perhaps using the property.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkCurve.JumpGap
member.summary: Like , but leaves a gap in the path when it crosses other orthogonal link segments. (Only applies when the route is orthogonal.)

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkAdjusting
member.summary: This enumeration describes how a computes its points.
member.remarks: This is used as the value of .

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkAdjusting.None
member.summary: Always discards any old points and recomputes all points according to standard policies.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkAdjusting.Scale
member.summary: When there are more than the standard number of points in the route, scale and rotate the intermediate points so that the link's shape stays approximately the same. This style, implemented by , does not maintain the horizontal and vertical line segments of an orthogonal link. Orthogonal links with this adjusting style will instead recalculate the standard route path, as if the adjusting style were .

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkAdjusting.Stretch
member.summary: When there are more than the standard number of points in the route, linearly interpolate the intermediate points along the X and Y dimensions between the ports. This style, implemented by , does not maintain the horizontal and vertical line segments of an orthogonal link. Orthogonal links with this adjusting style will instead only modify the end points of the existing path, as if the adjusting style were .

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkAdjusting.End
member.summary: When there are more than the standard number of points in the route, or if the route is orthogonal, just modify the end points, while leaving the intermediate points unchanged. This style maintains orthogonality for orthogonal links.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkRouting

member.remarks: This is used as the value of .

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkRouting.Normal
member.summary: The route only takes the link's two nodes into account.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkRouting.Orthogonal
F:Northwoods.GoXam.LinkRouting.AvoidsNodes
member.summary: The route tries to avoid crossing over other nodes. Currently this routing style also implies that it is . The other nodes must be .

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.DataTemplateDictionary
member.summary: This dictionary holds a number of DataTemplates indexed by category names.

remarks.para: There are three standard template collections: , , and . You can swap whole sets of data templates at once by setting those three properties.

However, the properties: , , and
take precedence over the value in this dictionary.

Caution: if you create a DataTemplateDictionary in XAML as the value of a Style Setter, that dictionary will be shared by all diagrams affected by that style. The same is true if you create the DataTemplateDictionary as a resource and refer to it in more than one diagram.
An instance of this dictionary may be shared by multiple s. However, if you modify this dictionary, no will be notified of such a change until you explicitly call .

member.summary: Modify the of the to a new point, considering also which reshape handle is being dragged and whether the route is .
member.remarks: If the is this modifies the adjacent points as well in order to keep adjacent segments orthogonal. For handles that are near either end of the route, the movement may be constrained to be only vertical or only horizontal, in order to maintain orthogonality. The decision is based on the value of on the . This method is called during a "ReshapeLink" transaction.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.LinkReshapingTool.ComputeReshape(System.Windows.Point)
member.summary: Compute the new Point for reshaping a point in the .
member.remarks: The value of on the determines what reshape constraints exist on that handle, for the point of the . If there are no reshape constraints, this just returns the value of . If the value is , the Y coordinate may vary according to the value provided by , but the X coordinate remains the same. If the value is , the X coordinate may change, but not the Y value. If the value is , the route point may not move.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.DragZoomingTool
member.summary: The DragZoomingTool lets the user zoom into a diagram by stretching a box to indicate the new contents of the diagram's viewport (the area of the model shown by the ).

remarks.para: The diagram that is zoomed by this tool is specified by the property. If the value is null, the tool zooms its own .

Although this is a mouse-move tool class handling a mouse-drag in the background, and there is a property, no such tool is installed initially -- that property is null. You can install this tool by creating an instance of it and setting that diagram property. However, although it , the and the are two other background-mouse-drag tools that are normally installed in a and will take precedence over this tool.

To make this mode-less tool effective, you can remove the other two background mouse-dragging tools and install this DragZoomingTool in XAML:
<go:Diagram ... DragSelectingTool="{x:Null}" PanningTool="{x:Null}" > <go:Diagram.DragZoomingTool> <go:DragZoomingTool /> </go:Diagram.DragZoomingTool> </go:Diagram>
This tool does not utilize any s or tool handles.
This tool does not edit the model.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.ResizingTool
member.summary: The ResizingTool is used to interactively change the size of an element.

remarks.para: This tool allows the user to resize an element of the selected part. Normally this works with s; it does not make sense for s and s.

You can limit the permitted minimum and maximum dimensions by setting and . For example,
<go:Diagram.ResizingTool> <go:ResizingTool MinSize="10 10" MaxSize="100 200"/> </go:Diagram.ResizingTool>
will make sure every interactive resizing operation results in the in having a width between 10 and 100 and in having a height between 10 and 200. Furthermore,
<go:Diagram.ResizingTool> <go:ResizingTool MinSize="NaN 10" MaxSize="NaN 200"/> </go:Diagram.ResizingTool>
will restrict the width to be whatever the 's original width was, whereas the height may be varied between 10 and 200.
The resizing will also respect the FrameworkElement properties: MinWidth, MaxWidth, MinHeight, and MaxHeight, that are one the .

You can also limit the width and/or height to be multiples of a particular size by setting . If either or both of these values are NaN, as they are by default, it will get the values from the node being resized: .

If either or both of the width and height are still NaN, it will look for a snapper node behind the (a node that has true) and then use its . If it cannot find any snapper node, it uses the diagram's if the diagram's is true.
This tool makes use of an , shown when the is selected, that includes some number of resize handles.
This tool conducts a model edit ( and ) while the tool is .

member.value: The default value is 9999 x 9999. The width and height must not be negative. A width of Double.NaN uses the 's original width; a height of Double.NaN uses its original height ().

member.summary: Show an with resize handles at points along the edge of bounds of the , if the node is selected and visible and if is true.

remarks.para: First this finds the element in the visual tree of the that should get the resize adornment and that the user will be able to resize interactively. It finds the element that has the property of the part. If the property is null, as it is by default, it uses the part's .
It then constructs the adornment template, associating it with the chosen resize element.

You can change the template used to create the adornment by setting . If that property is null, this uses a default template with eight resize handles at the four corners and at the middles of the four sides.
This only gives a resize adornment to s, not to s.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.PanningTool
member.summary: The PanningTool supports manual panning, where the user can shift the 's by dragging the mouse.

remarks.para: This tool is a standard mouse-move tool. Although is frequently able to return true, this tool is normally not run because other mouse-move tools will take precedence. In particular, the will run when the user drags in the diagram's background. Disable or remove the to enable background panning. Disable diagram selection or dragging to enable panning everywhere in the diagram.

For example, you can enable background panning by removing the drag-selecting tool:
<go:Diagram ... DragSelectingTool="{x:Null}" > </go:Diagram>
This tool does not utilize any s or tool handles.
This tool does not edit the model.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.DragSelectingTool
member.summary: The DragSelectingTool lets the user select multiple parts within a rectangular area drawn by the user.

remarks.para: This is a standard mouse-move tool, the . However this cannot start running unless there has been a motionless delay after the mouse-down event of at least milliseconds.

For example, you can change the selection policy in XAML by:
<go:Diagram ...> <go:Diagram.DragSelectingTool> <go:DragSelectingTool Include="Intersects" /> </go:Diagram.DragSelectingTool> </go:Diagram>
Or you can customize the default in code:
myDiagram.DragSelectingTool.Include = SearchInclusion.Intersects;
This tool does not utilize any s or tool handles.
This tool does not edit the model.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.DragSelectingTool.SelectInRect(System.Windows.Rect)
member.summary: This method is called to select some parts, governed by the value of .
member.remarks: The normal behavior is to set the diagram's selection collection to only those parts in the given rectangle according to the policy. However, if the Shift key modifier was used, no parts are deselected -- this adds to the selection the parts in the rectangle not already selected. If the Control key modifier was used, this toggles the selectedness of the parts in the rectangle. If the Control key and Shift key modifiers were both used, this deselects the parts in the rectangle.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.LinkingBaseTool.DoMouseMove
member.summary: Mouse movement results in the temporary node moving to where the valid is located, or to where the mouse is if there is no valid target port nearby.
member.remarks: This calls to update the given the new mouse point. If a valid target port is found, this calls to move the temporary node/port and make them appear like the target node/port. If no valid target port is found, this calls to move the temporary node to where the mouse currently is and to remove any node/port appearance.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.LinkingBaseTool.FindTargetPort(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Find a port with which the user could complete a valid link.
member.param: true if looking for a "to" port
member.returns: a FrameworkElement representing a valid port, or null if no such port is near the current mouse point (within distance)

remarks.para: This finds elements near to the current mouse point for which a valid link connection is possible. For example, when is true, this looks for elements (i.e. "ports") in nodes that have return true and for which is true.

For each port element found, this calls to find out if a link between the original node/port and the found node/port would be valid. The result is saved in the for faster decisions later during the operation of this tool. The closest valid port is returned.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.LinkingTool
member.summary: The LinkingTool lets a user draw a new between two ports, using a mouse-drag operation.

remarks.para: By default an instance of this tool is installed as a mouse-move tool in each , as the value of . calls to find a valid "port" element from which (or to which) the user may interactively draw a new link. sets up a temporary link and two temporary nodes, one at the start port and one following the mouse.
This tool does not utilize any s or tool handles.
This tool conducts a model edit ( and ) while the tool is .

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.LinkingTool.CanStart
member.summary: This tool can run when the diagram allows linking, the model is modifiable, the left-button mouse drag has moved far enough away to not be click, and when has returned a valid port.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.LinkingTool.FindLinkablePort
member.summary: Return the element at the mouse-down point, if it is part of a node and if it is valid to link with it.
member.returns: If the is or , this checks the element and its parent by calling . If the is or , this checks the element and its parent by calling . In either case finding a matching port will return that port and set in the appropriate direction. Otherwise this will return null.

remarks.para: If is non-null, it starts it search for a linkable "port" element at that element. The element may itself be a valid element to draw from or to. If is null, it finds the FrameworkElement at the .
Both and call this method, although the latter only does so if is null.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.LinkingTool.DoActivate
member.summary: Start the linking operation.

remarks.para: If is already set, it uses that element as the starting port. If it is not set, this calls and remembers the port as .

It then starts a model edit and changes the cursor. Next it initializes and adds the , , and to the diagram's . The temporary nodes that are positioned and sized to be like the real ( and ) ports by calling . The temporary link connects the two temporary nodes, of course.
The base method starts mouse capture.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.LinkingTool.DoDeactivate
member.summary: Finishing the linking operation stops the model edit and resets the cursor.
member.remarks: The base method cleans up the temporary nodes and links and releases the mouse capture.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.LinkingTool.DoStop
member.summary: Clean up tool state.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.LinkingTool.DoMouseUp
member.summary: A mouse-up ends the linking operation; if there is a valid nearby, this calls to create a new link.
member.remarks: If a new link is created in the model, the corresponding is selected in the diagram and the "link drawn" event is raised. In any case this stops the tool.

member.summary: This tool can run when the diagram allows relinking, the model is modifiable, and there is a relink handle at the mouse-down point.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.RelinkingTool.DoActivate
member.summary: Start the relinking operation.

remarks.para: Find the relink handle by calling looking for either the "RelinkFrom" handle or the "RelinkTo" handle, saving the result in .
This starts a model edit () and sets the cursor.

The value of is set depending on the category of relink handle found. The property and various "Original..." port and node properties are set too. The temporary nodes and temporary link are also initialized.
The base method starts mouse capture.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.RelinkingTool.DoDeactivate
member.summary: Finishing the relinking operation stops the model edit and resets the cursor.
member.remarks: The base method cleans up the temporary nodes and links and releases the mouse capture.

member.summary: Clean up tool state.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.RelinkingTool.DoMouseUp
member.summary: A mouse-up ends the relinking operation; if there is a valid nearby, this calls to delete the old link, and to create the replacement link.
member.remarks: The corresponding new is selected in the diagram and the "link relinked" event is raised. In any case this stops the tool.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether moving or copying a node also includes all of the node's children and their descendants, along with the links to those additional nodes.

remarks.para: When set to , will augment the collection of selected nodes to include their tree children nodes. The resulting collection often will include many s and s that are not .

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.DraggingTool.ComputeEffectiveCollection(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Northwoods.GoXam.Part})
member.summary: Find the actual collection of nodes and links to be moved or copied, given an initial collection.
member.returns: a Dictionary of s, mapped to s holding their original s

remarks.para: Besides the s in the collection, the result collection will include all member nodes and links, links whose connected nodes are both in the effective collection, and any link labels. This means that sometimes some or many of the parts that are dragged are not actually selected.

You may want to override this method to include additional parts that are related logically in some manner particular to your application. To handle the common case of wanting to move all of the tree-structure children of selected nodes, you can just set to .

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.DraggingTool.DropOnto(System.Windows.Point)
member.summary: Perform any additional side-effects after a drop.

remarks.para: If is true, and if the selection is dropped onto a that has set to , this will support re"parent"ing of nodes and links by adding them to the group. This calls to decide if the additional group membership is valid. If the selection is dropped onto the background, the selected nodes and links are removed from any groups of which they were a member and for which is also set to , and they are made into top-level nodes and links.

If the target has a set to or , this will support automatically adding a link from or to the dropped-on node with each of the dropped nodes. This calls to decide if the additional link relationship is valid.

If the target has a set to , this will support automatically removing that link and adding two links, one to and one from each of the dropped nodes, connecting with the two nodes that the original link had been connected with. This calls twice to decide if the additional link relationships are valid.

member.summary: Start a drag-and-drop operation.

remarks.para: This calls to create an which is passed to to actually start the drag-and-drop process.

If the result of the call to DoDragDrop returns DragDropEffects.None, this just cancels the operation of this dragging tool. If the result is DragDropEffects.Move and the data was moved to a different diagram, this will delete the original . Otherwise (if the result was a copy) this will move the dragged parts back to their original locations. Finally this stops this tool.

member.summary: Perform the drop of a drag-and-drop.

For internal or external copies ( or ), create copied parts or create parts from the external drag-and-drop data, move them to the final locations and select them. For an external move (), create parts from the external drag-and-drop data, move them appropriately, and select them.

Snapping behavior over a particular node is governed by the various "DragOverSnap..." properties on the node.

member.name: F:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.EffectiveCollectionInclusions.SubTree
member.summary: Include all standard connected parts and also tree-structure descendant nodes (children, grandchildren, etc.) and the links connecting to them. This assumes that links go from the parent node to their children, unless is , in which case links are assumed to go from each child to its parent node.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.TextEditingTool
member.summary: The TextEditingTool is used to let the user interactively edit text in place.

remarks.para: Typically this is used by setting the go:Part.TextEditable attached property to true on a particular TextBlock in a node. When the node is selected and the user clicks on the TextBlock or invokes the command, this tool is started and it uses an to perform in-place text editing. This text editor control is held in an so that it can be positioned in front of the TextBlock. (For more details see the description for .)

The TextBlock is accessible as the property. The text editor is accessible as the property; the adornment holding the editor is accessible as the property. From the text editor control one can access the TextBlock being edited via the to get to this tool, from which one can use the property.

You can disable mouse clicking from starting this text editing tool by setting to false. You can disable the F2 key from starting this text editing tool by making sure returns false, by either setting to false or by setting to false.

member.name: T:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.ToolManager
member.summary: This special is responsible for managing all of the 's mode-less tools.

remarks.para: Mode-less tools are tools that are present in one of the following lists: , , or . This ToolManager tool is normally the , so it is also often the .

When this tool is running as the current tool, it handles mouse-down, mouse-move, and mouse-up events. For each event it iterates over each of the tools in the corresponding list, calling its predicate. If that predicate returns true, it starts that tool by making it the diagram's current tool. It then activates the tool and passes on the event to the tool by calling the corresponding method (either , , or ).

Because this tool is typically the one running as the diagram's current tool when the user isn't "doing" anything, this tool can also handle other events, such as mouse wheel events. (WPF handles the standard keyboard events for diagrams via command bindings.)
This tool does not utilize any s or tool handles.
This tool does not edit the model.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.ToolManager.DoMouseDown
member.summary: Iterate over the and start the first one that .

remarks.para: A mouse down first tries to give focus to the .
Starting a tool replaces the with the new tool. Successfully doing so also activates the new tool by calling and passes on the mouse-down event to it by calling .
Not finding any startable tools causes this tool manager to activate, thereby enabling the mouse-move and mouse-up behaviors.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.ToolManager.DoMouseMove
member.summary: Iterate over the and start the first one that .

remarks.para: Starting a tool replaces the with the new tool. Successfully doing so also activates the new tool by calling and passes on the mouse-move event to it by calling .

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.ToolManager.DoMouseUp
member.summary: Iterate over the and start the first one that .

remarks.para: Starting a tool replaces the with the new tool. Successfully doing so also activates the new tool by calling and passes on the mouse-up event to it by calling .
If no startable tool is found it deactivates this tool manager, to get ready for a mouse-down and ignore mouse-move and mouse-up events.

member.name: M:Northwoods.GoXam.Tool.DiagramTool.DoStart
